name: A Cappella Council
description_preview: Council of a cappella groups on campus.
full_description: A council comprised of representatives from all groups to oversee a cappella activities on campus. Organizes interactions between groups, event scheduling, microphone usage, and arbitration of the audition process in the fall (and winter, if applicable).

name: Active Minds at the University of Chicago
description_preview: The national purpose of Active Minds is to empower university students to speak openly about mental health in order to educate others and encourage help-seeking behavior.
full_description: The national purpose of Active Minds is to empower university students to speak openly about mental health in order to educate others and encourage help-seeking behavior. The purpose of Active Minds on the University of Chicago campus is to connect students with the appropriate resources to better manage the rigors of the University, create a safe and welcoming space on campus to discuss mental health, inform students of the prevalence of mental health issues nationally, and provide a forum for those passionate about these issues to make a community impact.

name: African and Caribbean Students Association
description_preview: Celebrating the rich cultures of Africa and the Caribbean on campus.
full_description: ACSA aims to build a vibrant cultural community for African and Caribbean students at the University of Chicago. Our mission is to provide a space where students can deepen their understanding of the history and current issues affecting the Black diaspora. Through dynamic social, cultural, and political programs led by our governing board, we seek to engage the broader campus in meaningful learning and dialogue.

name: AI @ UChicago
description_preview: The purpose of this organization shall be to educate members on the ethics, use cases, and inner workings of AI. Furthermore, this RSO will seek to kindle a community surrounding the broad topic of AI.
full_description: DescriptionAI @ UChicago is a student-run organization dedicated to fostering understanding, exploration, and innovation in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Our community brings together students from diverse academic backgrounds who share a common interest in AI ethics, applications, and technologies. Through educational initiatives, hands-on projects, and community-building activities, AI @ UChicago provides its members with opportunities to learn, collaborate, and grow in this rapidly evolving field. What We Do Educational Programming:We offer a range of educational opportunities designed to deepen members' understanding of AI concepts, ethics, and applications. Our workshops, seminars, and speaker series feature experts from academia and industry who share insights and expertise on cutting-edge AI topics. Hands-on Projects:Members have the opportunity to engage in hands-on AI projects with each other, where they can apply their knowledge to real-world challenges. Whether it's developing AI algorithms, building AI-powered applications, or exploring machine learning techniques, our projects provide valuable experience and skill-building opportunities. Community Building:AI @ UChicago fosters a vibrant and inclusive community where members can connect, collaborate, and support one another. We organize speaker series, networking opportunities, and AI related activities to facilitate meaningful connections and friendships among members. Join Us:Whether you're a seasoned AI enthusiast or just curious about the field, AI @ UChicago welcomes students of all backgrounds and skill levels. Join us to explore the fascinating world of AI, connect with like-minded peers, and embark on a journey of learning, discovery, and innovation.

name: Aikido Kokikai
description_preview: Kokikai Aikido is a self-defense art that uses throws, pins, and an opponent's momentum to defend against striking and grabbing attacks.  For maximum effect, students learn how to relax properly and develop good posture and balance.
full_description: Kokikai Aikido is a self-defense art that uses throws, pins, and an opponent's momentum to defend against striking and grabbing attacks. For maximum effect, students learn how to relax properly and develop good posture and balance.

name: Allied Scholars for Animal Protection UChicago
description_preview: UChicago Allied Scholars for Animal Protection provides a unified infrastructure for sustainable and effective animal advocacy on college campuses, including ongoing logistical support, funding, educational programming, and career mentorships.

name: Alpha Kappa Psi (Beta Epsilon)
description_preview: Alpha Kappa Psi is America's oldest, largest, and most successful professional business fraternity.

name: Alpha Phi Omega
description_preview:
Alpha Phi Omega is a national co-ed community service fraternity. Our cardinal principles are leadership, friendship, and service. We participate in social and service events throughout the city. 
If you need volunteers, email uchi.apo.service@gmail.com

name: American Constitution Society
description_preview: The American Constitution Society is an organization of progressive law students, professors, and legal professionals. ACS works to uphold the Constitution by ensuring that the law is a force for protecting our democracy and the public interest.
full_description: The American Constitution Society is a national organization of law students, law professors, practicing lawyers and others. ACS realizes the promises of the U.S. Constitution by building and leading a diverse legal community that dedicates itself to advancing and defending democracy, justice, equality, and liberty; to securing a government that serves the public interest; and to guarding against the abuse of law and the concentration of power. ACS believes that the Constitution is “of the people, by the people, and for the people.” We interpret the Constitution based on its text and against the backdrop of history and lived experience. Through a diverse nationwide network of progressive lawyers, law students, judges, scholars and many others, we work to uphold the Constitution in the 21st Century by ensuring that law is a force for protecting our democracy and the public interest and for improving people’s lives. ACS welcomes a diverse membership into our network from a wide range of communities, including people of different ethnic and racial backgrounds, gender, physical abilities, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, socioeconomic status, religious and spiritual values, and national origin. These members are critical to ACS’s mission of building and leading a diverse legal community that dedicates itself to advancing and defending democracy, justice, equality, and liberty; to securing a government that serves the public interest; and to guarding against the abuse of law and the concentration of power. All those in the ACS family are called upon to actively and affirmatively participate in creating and promoting a more inclusive and diverse American Constitution Society.

name: American Lung Cancer Screening Initiative
description_preview: Do you want to gain patient exposure and clinical hours talking to individuals about lung cancer screening? ALCSI strives to increase lung cancer screening awareness. Interested in making tangible impact and saving lives? Email rico1604@uchicago.edu
full_description: The American Lung Cancer Screening Initiative (ALCSI) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that consists of a network of students and doctors across the nation, striving to increase lung cancer screening awareness. Among all the university chapters of ALCSI, our UChicago chapter is uniquely positioned on the Southside of Chicago. Everyday we work to increase screening within the Southside of Chicago. We are partnered with the UChicago Medicine Screening Center and many other leaders who aim to decrease health inequity. Our goals are to make tangible impacts that save lives. Lung Cancer is the number one cause of cancer related death. In its early stages, lung cancer is often curable, but it is also silent. Thus, there is no way to detect it, except for screenings. However, if the lung cancer gets to late stages, it will metastasize. At that point, life expectancy is generally 2 years. Thus, screening is critical for saving lives. However, as of 2024, only 6% of vulnerable individuals are getting screened for lung cancer. Our team organizes grassroots events in the Southside of Chicago. We speak to thousands of individuals about lung cancer screening and help them determine if they are eligible for the screening. Our hardworking team members can be found at churches, festivals, health fairs, and food pantries. When they aren't in the field, they're writing thousands of emails to organize more events and helping enroll patients to get them screened. If these words speak to you, consider joining our team! This organization is not low commitment, as we seek individuals who are extremely passionate about our goals. We are a family and will help each other as needed, so you're never alone. You don't need to be a pre-med to join this extremely strategy oriented club. However, if you are, you will gain many unique clinical hours.

description_preview:
Organization purpose: 
1)Improving quality of health care in the US and worldwide, 2) Acting as a resource for social and moral interests in medical education, and 3) Protecting the interests of medical students and residents
full_description: Organization purpose:1)Improving quality of health care in the US and worldwide, 2) Acting as a resource for social and moral interests in medical education, and 3) Protecting the interests of medical students and residents

name: American Red Cross of University of Chicago
description_preview: The American Red Cross of University of Chicago (ARCUC) is a collegiate club of the American Red Cross of Greater Chicago (ARCGC) chapter. We seek to take a strong leadership role in recruiting support for the Red Cross and our surrounding communities.
full_description: The American Red Cross is a humanitarian organization, led by volunteers, that provides relief to victims of disasters, and helps people prevent, prepare for, and respond to emergencies. It does this through services that are consistent with its congressional charter and the principles of the International Red Cross Movement. In addition, the American Red Cross of University of Chicago will develop and offer services that address critical human, health, and safety needs of the communities which it serves and are consistent with the American Red Cross Mission. What do we do throughout the year? We meet four times a quarter for half hour or less! We coordinate and run several blood drives throughout the year, teach CPR certification classes, host clothing drives for charity, have baking or donuts sales to raise funds for the Red Cross, and participate in national Red Cross events like Sound the Alarm! Who can come to our meetings? Anyone and everyone! You can become a member by joining our Blueprint page and emailing Nino at npusateri@uchicago.edu or by just showing up to any meeting we have, but you don't have to be a member to come to the meetings. Everyone is welcome! Email npusateri@uchicago.edu with any and all questions! Also, Check out our website http://redcross.uchicago.edu/

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website:: American Red Cross of Greater Chicago

name: Animal Legal Defense Fund - The University of Chicago Law School
description_preview: ALDF is dedicated to providing a forum for education, advocacy, and scholarship aimed at protecting the lives and advancing the interests of animals through the legal system.
full_description: ALDF is dedicated to providing a forum for education, advocacy, and scholarship aimed at protecting the lives and advancing the interests of animals through the legal system.  ALDF is dedicated to the goals of educating the law school and surrounding community about forms of institutionalized animal abuse, and engaging in projects that combat that abuse.  ALDF is equally dedicated to raising the profile of the field of animal law.

name: Ankara Magic
description_preview: Afrobeats Dance Team
full_description: Ankara Magic is UChicago's first and only African dance group. We are a team that fosters and encourages community through dance. We teach and perform African dance choreography in Afrobeats, Amapiano, Afropop and other dance styles rooted in African dance genres, all choreographed by students. We perform our very own showcase as well as at multiple events throughout the school year including Black Convocation, ACSA Culture Show, OBS Culture Show, Where Fun Comes to Dance and other RSO events/collaborations.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Wednesdays and Sundays Ida Noyes dance room

name: Anthropology Students Association
description_preview: The University of Chicago Anthropology Students Association was set up to promote anthropology and anthropology-related research and events at the University of Chicago. The association is open to all members of the University of Chicago community.
full_description: The University of Chicago Anthropology Students Association promotes anthropology and anthropology-related research and events at the University of Chicago. The association is open to all members of the University of Chicago community.

name: Apsara
description_preview: Apsara is UChicago's premier classical Indian dance company. We produce full-length shows in the winter and spring, and participate in the annual SASA (South Asian Students Association) show. We welcome dancers of all backgrounds and levels!
full_description: Apsara provides a forum for the practice, discussion, and performance of Indian classical dance (primarily Bharatanatyam, Kathak, Kuchipudi, and Odissi). It also seeks to increase awareness of South Asian culture within the University community by being inclusive of beginners, performing at various events on campus, and addressing a range of topics through thematic performances. Apsara is open to collaborating with other organizations for performances, workshops, and classes as well!

name: Arab Student Association
description_preview: We aim to cultivate an active community for Arab students and students interested in Arab culture, heritage, and identity at the University of Chicago and to support the community with a range of professional development opportunities.
full_description: The ASA aims to cultivate an active community for Arab students and students interested in Arab culture, heritage, and identity at the University of Chicago and to support the community with a range of professional development opportunities. We hope to build a stronger presence through regular group events aimed at exploring and celebrating the diverse forms of Arab culture (study breaks, music and trivia nights, art shows, historical expositions), and we aim to create a platform for networking opportunities in or related to the Middle East through career fairs, talks by prominent Arabs in a range of fields, and funding trips to Arab conferences outside the University.

name: Archery
description_preview:
The University of Chicago Archery Club's main goal is to promote the sport of archery at both a competitive and a non-competitive level.

For more information, please email us at ArcheryBoard@lists.uchicago.edu
full_description: The University of Chicago Archery Club's main goal is to promote the sport of archery at both a competitive and a non-competitive level. To achieve this, Archery is divided into the Archery Team and the Archery Club. The Archery Team is intended for students who want to take archery as a serious team sport. However, no previous experience in target archery is necessary. Beginners to professionals are all welcomed! Team members will have the opportunity to travel and compete with other college archery teams, whilst being subsidized by the team. Additionally, members will be instructed by a professional archery coach. The Archery Club is intended as a safe and fun activity for all university staff and students to practice and improve their skills with a bow. Come to as many, or as few practices, as you would like, and feel free to come late or leave early. No experience is necessary, and is often encouraged. Beginners to professionals are all welcomed! For e-mailed practice times and announcements, subscribe to our listhost at Archery@lists.uchicago.edu. Subscriptions can be made by logging into lists.uchicago.edu and searching for our listhost. Alternatively, you can e-mail ArcheryBoard@lists.uchicago.edu and ask to be added by a web administrator. We hope to see you soon!

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Club Practices: Thursday 7:00PM-8:30PM, Saturday 12PM-1:30.  Team Practice: Monday 7:00-8:30PM Always in Henry Crown Fieldhouse

description_preview: The Argentine Tango Club promotes Argentine Tango on the University of Chicago campus. We organize Argentine Tango classes, dance parties and events showcasing Argentine Tango in literature, figurative arts, Argentine traditions and music history.
full_description: Organization Purpose:Promote Argentine Tango on the University of Chicago campus.The Argentine Tango Club promotes Argentine Tango in all its artistic expressions: thedance (a classical, clean style, good posture, musicality, and a comfortable, solid connection), but also the music and the "tango culture" (in literature, figurative arts, Argentine traditions).

name: Armenian Students Association
description_preview: The Armenian Students' Association is a group of students interested in the Armenian language, culture, and greater nation. We aim to explore Armenian identity within the University at large, through our storied history, culture, politics, and traditions
full_description: The Armenian Students' Association is a group of students interested in the Armenian language, culture, and greater nation. We aim to explore Armenian identity within the University at large, through our storied history, culture, politics, and traditions. In addition, our purpose is to engage the entire university community, through open cultural events and fundraisers for Armenian charities. The group meets regularly in connection with the Armenian Circle events (organized through the NELC Department), and organizes a Cultural Event and Armenian food-making events throughout the year. Membership is open to any registered student of the University of Chicago.

name: ArtShould
description_preview: ArtShould is an arts community service RSO that aims to promote art on the University of Chicago campus and in the Hyde Park community. We mentor youths in Chicago Public Schools through after-school art programs and host creative events on campus.
full_description: ArtShould is an arts community service RSO that aims to promote art on the University of Chicago campus and in the Hyde Park community. We mentor youths in Chicago Public Schools through after-school art programs, helping them learn how to express and empower themselves creatively through art. These programs offer the opportunity to give children not only valuable skills and tools, but also the confidence that comes from self-expression. Additionally, we organize creative events and interactive projects for University of Chicago students. ArtShould is dedicated to realizing art's potential as a collaborative experience and a safe medium for self-expression.

name: Asian American InterVarsity
description_preview: Following Jesus, Living His Kingdom, Renewing our Campus
full_description: Our Beliefs:AAIV is part of a much bigger movement that spans the nation. Intervarsityis “an evangelical campus mission serving more than 32,000 students andfaculty on more than 550 college and university campuses nationwide.” Whatwe believe is reflected inIntervarsity’s Doctrinal Basis. To learn more about Intervarsity USA, please visit the website athttp://www.intervarsity.org/.

name: Asian Pacific American Medical Students Association
description_preview: The University of Chicago Asian Pacific American Medical Students Association (APAMSA) seeks to promote health and wellness for all Asian and Pacific Islander communities and to encourage University of Chicago students to serve these patient populations.
full_description: APAMSA is a student-led organization at the Pritzker School of Medicine that is dedicated to raising awareness of Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) health disparities and providing a much-needed space for medical students and physicians to connect over shared challenges in pursuing careers in medicine as AAPI. Here are some of the projects that APAMSA is working on currently: 1) APAMSA recently initiated a cultural humility program with the Bridgeport Free Clinic (BFC) to help Pritzker medical students learn more about the predominantly Chinese American patient population served by the BFC in order to better serve them. 2) APAMSA recently established a mentorship program, supported by the Office of Multicultural Students Affairs, for pre-medical students identifying as Asian/Pacific American (AAPI) at the University of Chicago. This program is a chance for AAPI pre-medical students to meet with AAPI medical students who have similar upbringings and callings to medicine and receive guidance on studying, medical school applications, and tips on opportunities to pursue to learn more about various pathways in health professions. 3) APAMSA is partnering with the South Asian Medical Students Association (SAMSA) in organizing the inaugural conferenceAsians in Medicine: A Conference on Advocacy and Allyshipon May 18th. The objectives of this conference are threefold. The first is to raise awareness of Asian American health disparities, such as the disproportionately high prevalence of HBV and diabetes, as well as to highlight the work of nonprofit organizations to serve the needs of various Asian American ethnic enclaves throughout Chicago, such as Chinatown and Devon. The second objective is to have Asian American medical leaders based throughout Chicago to meet with participants to talk about their career paths and to provide guidance on how to overcome the “bamboo ceiling” to pursue leadership positions in medicine. The final objective of the conference is to talk more critically about Asian Americans’ position as overrepresented minorities in highly privileged professions such as medicine; discuss strategies for partnering with other communities of color to develop a common agenda for addressing systemic health disparities; and to provide a space for participants to talk about challenges faced by Asian American health professionals that are often ignored, such as microaggressions from colleagues and racism from patients. Please contact us if you have any questions about APAMSA's projects and joining our wonderful organization!

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website::
Asian Pacific American Medical Students Association 
apamsa.org

name: Asian Policy Forum
description_preview: APF connects students with various leaders and experts of Asia-related policies to inspire conversations on Asian issues, and enhance diversity and inclusion through organizing cultural events. With us, you will grasp the dynamics of Asia and policies.
full_description: The Asian Policy Forum aims to connect students with various leaders and experts of Asia-related policies to initiate enriching discourse and inspire conversations on Asian issues.  We also develop the understanding of Asian cultures through organizing cultural events to celebrate and enhance diversity and inclusion. With us, you will grasp the dynamics of Asia, and look at policies in a global context.

name: Association for Women in Mathematics
description_preview: We support women in mathematics.
full_description: We aim to encourage and support women in the specific discipline of mathematics. In particular, we would like to bring together women undergraduates, graduates and members of faculty in the mathematics department, to provide mutual support and to increase the visibility of women in mathematics. Some of the activities of our organization include having speakers, either from the U of C community or elsewhere, to discuss issues relating to women in math, running a mentoring program for women in math, and providing online resources for women in math.

name: Badminton
description_preview: The UC Badminton Club provides a forum for members to play recreational badminton regularly at the university, as well as occasional opportunities for competitive badminton at tournaments and matches with nearby schools.
full_description: We welcome players of all skill levels, so feel free to drop by at any time during club hours! The club supplies nets, net-anchors, shuttlecocks, and a limited number of racquets for lending out, which are paid for by a small membership fee as well as some money supplied by the university. The membership fee is$5 Drop-in/$18 quarterly/$45 annually. Our practice schedule is attinyurl.com/uchicagobadminton. Please also sign up for ouremailing list You can see more info and our social media channels, check out ourlinktree For any questions or concerns, email us or message us through ourinstagrampage

name: Baha'i Association of the University of Chicago
description_preview: The goal of the Baha'i Association is to create a forum for discussion and action based on the writings and teachings of the Baha'i Faith and interfaith dialogue with other world Faiths.
full_description: The goal of the Baha'i Association is to create a forum for discussion and action based on the writings and teachings of the Baha'i Faith and interfaith dialogue. We believe the guidance provided by the teachings and principles of the Baha'i Faith, set forth in the writings of Baha'u'llah and shared by all world Faiths,  are valuable resources for personal transformation or to augment any course of study, be it economics, sociology, the visual and dramatic arts, philosophy, or the physical sciences. Thus, our activities and events (discussion groups, devotional gatherings, community involvement, lectures, etc.) are designed for anyone and everyone interested in personal or social change through these principles.

name: Ballroom and Latin Dance Association
description_preview: BLDA is dedicated to promoting the awareness and appreciation of Ballroom and Social Latin dance on campus by providing dance lessons and social dance events for both UChicago and the city of Chicago. We are home to UChicago's Competitive Ballroom Team.
full_description: BLDA teaches weekly lessons in both social Latin and competitive ballroom styles. We host a variety of social dance events on campus, and we also host monthly social Latin events at The Promontory in Hyde Park. In addition, the UChicago Competitive Ballroom Team BLDA trains and practices to travel around the Midwest and compete with other universities in our DanceSport circuit.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: TBA depending on space, join listhost for schedule

name: Bite Culinary Magazine
description_preview: A quarterly print culinary magazine and online blog for those interested in food-writing and photography, including features, recipes, and reviews.
full_description: Bite is a quarterly print culinary magazine and online blog focused on features, recipes, and reviews of culinary institutions in Chicago. The aim of Bite will be to foster interest in and knowledge of culinary techniques and events, as well as to provide a platform for food enthusiasts to share their discoveries and experiences. It also includes collaborations with Chicago restaurants and corresponding advertisements.

name: Black Action in Public Policy Studies
description_preview: Black Action in Public Policy Studies (BAPPS), is committed to cultivating an inclusive community for our members. Through our programming, we center the experiences and needs of Black people when delving into issues of inequality within public policy.
full_description: BAPPS Mission BAPPS is a student-led organization, at the Harris School of Public Policy, committed touplifting Black students at Harris, as well as highlighting and addressing the policy and socialissues impacting the global Black community. We aim to celebrate all members of this richdiaspora across our intersecting identities. To achieve this mission we will devise initiatives that:❖ supporting Black Harris students via creating safe spaces and professional opportunities❖ facilitate critical discourse on inequities harming Black people❖ increase public awareness on the poignant matters salient to varying Black communities❖ actively engage in acts of service that work to strengthen Black communities❖ humanize and advocate on behalf of Black lives BAPPS Vision At BAPPS we envision a strong Black community at Harris, where Black students can thrive andmaximize their potential for excellence while at Harris, and beyond their tenure with the school.We also envision a world where Black social issues across the diaspora are paid attention to,discussed with intentionality, and addressed with proper care. We believe that in our trek tosocial equity for Black communities, we will overcome the persisting hindrances to progress.Moreover, we hope to celebrate the sacrifice and fight of those who came before us in a pursuitof Black liberation across the globe. BAPPS also introduces our... BLACK POLICY REVIEW BPR Mission To empower, inform, and challenge prevailing narratives in ways that transform the black experience. We seek to tell stories that inspire, galvanize, and advocate for a more inclusive approach to policy analysis that respects and highlights the lived experiences of Black and African Diaspora communities. BPR Vision To be the leading academic publication for policy research and analysis that specifically caters to socioeconomic and political issues or concerns that impact Black and African Diaspora communities, both domestic and abroad. We aim to promote a dialogue that spurs conversations that lead to effective policy outcomes.

name: Black Law Students Association
description_preview: The purpose of this organization is to articulate, promote, and discuss issues of concern to Black law students and to facilitate the interaction between Black law students, current members and alumni of the Law School and the Chicago community.
full_description: The purpose of this organization is to articulate, promote, and discuss issues of concern to Black law students and to facilitate the interaction between Black law students, current members and alumni of the University of Chicago Law School and the Chicago community.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website:: National Black Law Students Association - http://www.nblsa.org

name: Black Student Fellowship
description_preview: Spring 2024 New RSO
full_description: The mission of Black Student Fellowship is to create a safe space and community for Black-Identifying UChicago students to explore and grow in their faith. We typically host weekly Bible studies on various topics related to Christianity and Blackness. We also host study breaks, volunteer events, and trips to various churches in Hyde Park and Chicago. Overall, we seek to connect with students and foster a greater sense of community and support on campus.

name: BlackGen Capital
description_preview: Spring 2024 New RSO
full_description: BlackGen Capital exists to serve minorities that are underrepresented in the financial services industry and business world. The organization’s purpose is to reduce the barriers that said minorities face when trying to access these fields by cultivating an environment that is not only educating but acts as a platform & network that members can professionally leverage. ​ We foster a community of talented Black, Hispanic, and Native American students who are interested in paying it forward and becoming the next generation of finance professionals. With the mission of closing the access gap for talented minority students, we provide our members the opportunity to attend private networking events and receive recruitment insight from our dedicated corporate sponsors.

name: Blacklight Magazine
description_preview: Blacklight Magazine is a collective of young creatives and a platform for marginalized voices. We create visual and literary art. We transform. We disrupt tradition.
full_description: Blacklight is a literary and arts publication showcasing work from queer and BIPOC creatives. Our magazine aims to provide a platform for the voices of historically marginalized individuals on campus and across the broader Chicago area. Along with publishing quarterly, we hold events, workshops, and talks throughout the year.All are welcome to join!

name: Blockchain Chicago
description_preview: Blockchain Chicago aims to unite the university communities growing around blockchain technology by promoting and constructing quality, multidisciplinary, educational experiences for curious and inquisitive souls.
full_description: Blockchain Chicago is an official RSO (Recognized Student Organization) at the University of Chicago. We aim to facilitate an environment where students and enthusiasts are empowered to engage in blockchain related entrepreneurial and educational pursuits.We distribute information about events/meetings on ourwebsiteand ourinstagram.Connect with us:http://linktr.ee/blockchainchicago

name: Blue Chips
description_preview: Founded in 2003, The Blue Chips is the University of Chicago’s premier investment club. As a group of over 50 active undergraduate members, we manage a $170,000 fundamental value-focused equity portfolio, gifted to us by Greg Wendt (A.B. '83).
full_description: Founded in 2003, The Blue Chips is the University of Chicago’s premier investment club. As a group of over 50 active undergraduate members, we manage a $190,000 fundamental value-focused equity portfolio, gifted to us by Greg Wendt (A.B. '83). Our mission is to provide an authentic value investing experience through the practical application of valuation methodologies and active portfolio management. New members must be admitted through an application and interview process. Applications are open to first- and second-year students in the Fall and Winter quarters. All relevant information is available at:tbc.uchicago.edu/apply.

name: Boxing Club
description_preview: Boxing Club Sport
full_description: We teach anybody with any experience level how to box, and offer a community of people to actively train and spar with. People from all backgrounds of martial arts and schools within the University come to our club to continue training. We'd love to see you! We train out of Crown Field House, and our schedule will drop soon! Stay in touch through our ListHost and Messenger!

name: Brazilian Student Association
description_preview: The Brazilian Student Association (BSA) is committed to bringing the Brazilian culture to the University of Chicago. We bring the Brazilian community and those interested in Brazil together to share experiences in a variety of events throughout the year.
full_description: The Brazilian Student Association (BSA) stands as a community of students in the University of Chicago who endeavor to raise awareness about Brazil around campus. Our members serve as Brazilian Ambassadors on campus, focused on: (1) Organizing and publicizing events that (a) disseminate Brazilian culture and (b) promote the discussion on topics related to Brazilian culture, economy and politics. (2) Strengthening the Brazilian community among all schools in the University, as to (a) serve as a network platform for all those interested in pursuing professional, academic and/or personal opportunities in Brazil, (b) make up for the physical distance by serving as a “home away from home” to the Brazilians on campus.

name: Bridge Club
description_preview:
We are a social club that plays bridge every week during the school term. We also play in several tournaments per year.

Our meetings are Thursdays from 8-11pm; stay as long as you want. We're happy to teach beginners.
full_description: For the most up-to-date information, please subscribe to our listhost at https://lists.uchicago.edu/web/info/bridge.

name: Bridge to College
description_preview: The purpose of Bridge to College is to help underserved Chicago Public School high school students develop a stronger working knowledge of what college and the application process entails through College Days and our one-on-one mentorship program.
full_description: The purpose of Bridge to College is to help underserved Chicago Public School high school students develop a stronger working knowledge of what college and the application process entails by bringing them to campus for College Days and our weekly mentorship program. Examples of events for College Days include the following: We would love to have you join us in helping CPS high school students learn more about pursuing a college education! Please reach out if you are interested in volunteering for a College Day or being a mentor for a CPS high school student on the college application process.

name: Bridgeport Free Clinic
description_preview: The mission of the Bridgeport Free Clinic (BFC) is to provide drop-in medical care for the uninsured community of Bridgeport.
full_description: The mission of the Bridgeport Free Clinic (BFC) is to provide drop-in medical care for the uninsured community of Bridgeport, where 35% of the population is Asian and, of the 22% uninsured in the community area, the largest proportion (28%) is of Asian descent. The clinic focuses on basic care for conditions that affect that population more commonly, including hypertension, diabetes, high cholesterol, Hepatitis B, liver disease, and smoking. In addition, the clinic aims to help enroll patients in insurance through in-house navigators for the Affordable Care Act, and refer to primary care doctors in the community for long-term care. Interpretive services in Cantonese, Mandarin, and Spanish are available for all clinic patients.

name: Business Organization for Latino Development
description_preview: BOLD is the premier community for Latino business professionals at UChicago
full_description: The Business Organization for Latino Development (BOLD) is UChicago’s premier organization for Latino students interested in pursuing careers in business. Founded in 2021 in response to the lack of Latino representation across business clubs, BOLD strives to develop, motivate, and celebrate Latino students on campus. Through weekly education workshops, guest speaker series with top Latino business leaders, and exclusive networking events, BOLD exposes its members to various career paths within business. Moreover, BOLD offers tight-knit Finance and Consulting tracks, which coach students on various behavioral and technical skills prior to and throughout their recruiting process.

name: Cadenza
description_preview: A high voice a cappella group serenading UChicago since 1989, previously named "Unaccompanied Women."
full_description: Cadenza is the oldest a cappella group at the University of Chicago, founded in 1989 under the name "Unaccompanied Women" as a high-voices ensemble. We pride ourselves on telling stories through our music and spreading 'Denza love every chance we get. All of our songs are arranged by members, past and present. On campus, we’re known for our annual Singing Valentines, our concerts and archsings, and our chaotic fun-loving spirit. We compete in the ICCAs every other year and record music as often as possible. Our EP “Let Me,” featuring our 2018 ICCA set, has appeared on several national compilation albums and even recently received a CARA! Our sophomore full-length album, "I Tried to Love You" released at the beginning of Fall 2023 -- available on all major streaming services! You can find us on Facebook, Instagram, Youtube, and your streaming service of choice.

name: Campus Catalyst
description_preview: campusCATALYST is a student-run organization at the University of Chicago that engages in high-impact pro bono consulting with local Chicago non-profits.
full_description: Campus Catalyst offers students a formal introduction to non-profits and an applied introduction to consulting. Every quarter, we match 5 groups of 5 students with a Booth MBA mentor or Harris graduate student and Chicago-based non-profit which has identified an operational or strategic concern that they would like student consulting on. Students are concurrently enrolled in a public policy department class: The Business of Non-profits and the Evolving Social Sector. We also run speaker events, a case competition, coffee chats, and more.

name: Cana
description_preview: Cana is a student-run Christian journal that publishes creative content exploring faith in a university setting. Our mission is to engage with relevant topics in the space where the "life of the mind" meets a call to discipleship.
full_description: Cana is a student-run, interdenominational Christian journal that publishes creative content (essays, poems, short stories, devotionals, and visual art) exploring faith in a university setting. Our mission is to engage with relevant topics in the space where the "life of the mind" meets a call to follow Jesus Christ.

name: Catcher in the Rhyme
description_preview: Catcher in the Rhyme is a student-run organization to encourage self-expression through spoken word poetry both on campus and off.
full_description: Whether through open mics, weekly meetings, or hosting and attending events, Catcher in the Rhyme seeks to promote the voice of the individual. Slam poetry has a unique ability to highlight both the facts and more personal pieces of any given event, making it a highly powerful tool and a deeply touching art form. It's a medium for stories that resonate deeply and one for tales nearly akin to stand up comedy: whatever you've been dying to say, you can say it here, and we'd be more than happy to have you. In the past, we've heard poems about lost love, politics, Burger King wedding vows, and so much more. We're here to make sure that the many talented voices of our community have the chance to explore the genre, learning and growing as writers, performers, and people. Okay, you get it, it's a good time. But what's itactuallylike to be a member? During each meeting, we partake in free-writing and tea-spilling, ending with a fun writing activity. Outside of weekly meetings, poets are encouraged to participate in more rigorous (and often more exciting) projects such as group performances. And of course, sharing your words with the people around you means you're more than likely to make a few new friends, too.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Tuesdays @ 6:00 pm- 7:00 pm in the Logan Center for the Arts (802)

name: Catholic Students Association
description_preview: This is a group dedicated to developing Catholic community in the student population of the University of Chicago through various social, service, and spiritual activities.
full_description: The Catholic Students Association (CSA) aims to build a social community around the Catholic population on campus at the University of Chicago, including both those practicing and those interested in the Catholic faith, by planning, funding, executing, and participating in service, spiritual, and social events.

name: Catholic Students Association for Graduate and Professional Students
description_preview: We aim to foster a community of Catholic graduate students, professional students, friends, and interested parties of any religious belief, through spiritual, social and service events.
full_description: We are a group of Catholic graduate and professional students who meet throughout the quarter to share food and fellowship. Non-Catholics are always welcome.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Fridays (3-4 times/quarter), 7 pm, Calvert House basement

name: Center for Leadership and Involvement
description_preview: The Center for Leadership and Involvement supports the goals of the University of Chicago by creating meaningful involvement opportunities and fostering inclusive environments which advance student learning.
full_description: The Center for Leadership and Involvement is a multi-faceted office that encourages student involvement at the University of Chicago and provides learning opportunities in ways as diverse and valuable as possible, while enhancing the unique culture of the University. We look forward to working with your student group this year to create a community of student leaders who work together to encourage and enrich student life at the University of Chicago!

name: Central Asian Studies Society
description_preview: The Central Asian Studies Society promotes the study of and engagement with the histories, languages, and cultures of Central Asia. We define Central Asia broadly, stretching from the Caspian Sea and Afghanistan to Xinjiang and Mongolia.
full_description: The Central Asian Studies Society (CASS) was formed at the University of Chicago in the winter of 2001. Our primary objective is to expand both the academic and public communities' engagement with the peoples, histories, languages, and cultures of Central Asia. CASS emphasizes promoting Central Asian studies in academia, and we also work with members of Central Asian diaspora communities to publicly present the vibrancy Central Asian cultures. We attempt to meet our objective by sponsoring events such as lectures, films, musical performances, and cultural events.

name: Chabad
description_preview: Chabad provides a friendly and welcoming environment for everyone on campus to celebrate Jewish festivities, expand their knowledge of Judaism, pray, and meet new friends.
full_description: UChicago Chabad provides a friendly and welcoming environment for everyone on campus to celebrate Jewish festivities, expand their knowledge of Judaism, pray, and meet new friends. We are proud to host home-cooked Shabbat dinner, open to the entire community, nearly every week. Don't hesitate to stop by for Shabbat, Cafe Shira, or just to say hi!

name: Charles River Economics Labs
description_preview: We are a group of undergraduate researchers at UChicago who conduct pro bono economic policy research for governments, intergovernmental organizations, and policy think tanks. Please contact us if you are interested in this unique opportunity!
full_description: Established in June 2021,Charles River Economics Labs, Corp., is a group of undergraduates at the University of Chicago, Harvard University and Stanford University that conducts pro-bono scientific research and publication in the field of economics. The group partners with intergovernmental organizations, think tanks, and nonprofit organizations in doing so, with the main goal of supporting policymakers through pro-bono research. Our work involves the study, determination, and interpretation of economic, political, and social facts relating to questions of significance on behalf of our clients. Our research is conducted using objective scientific principles and academic norms – our conclusions are based on empirical evidence without regard to the special interests of any group in the body politic for governments and nonprofit organizations. For example, in Fall 2023 we worked with the Census Bureau to create a novel comprehensive dataset on the US Cannabis Industry, analyzing trends in license issuance, dispensary concentration, product pricing, etc. We presented our results to the Census ADEP Team and discussed the policy implications of our findings. Ultimately, our goal is to influence positive, welfare-maximizing change in public policy through economic analysis. Some of our former and current project partners across our 3 chapters include: Federal Agencies (Departments of Transportation, Commerce, Energy, State, Census Bureau), the UN Development Programme, Chelsea Public Schools, Brookings Institution, World Bank, and NASA.

name: Cheerleading
description_preview: UC Cheer stunts, dances, cheers, and tumbles to pump up school spirit, not just at basketball and football games, but all over the school. Check out our Facebook and Instagram pages for updates on workshops, tryouts, games, and events!

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Tuesdays and Wednesdays 7-9pm on the Henry Crown Field House Balcony, and Sundays 4:30-6:30pm on the Henry Crown Field House Balcony

name: Chemistry Society (Benzene)
description_preview: Benzene is a chemistry interest club for undergraduate and graduate students.
full_description: Benzene is a chemistry interest club for undergraduate students of all majors. Meetings are held every week, and topics vary from student presentations on research to faculty talks. Join our listhost via this website: https://lists.uchicago.edu/web/suboptions/benzene Benzene also serves as a social group where chemistry majors, biochemistry majors, and others interested in the chemical sciences can meet, hang out, and ask questions about research, graduate school, and other topics. Benzene hosts a yearly seminar, the Gregory Hillhouse Memorial lecture (previously the "Benzene Lecture") in which we invite a distinguished chemist to give a lecture and meet with undergraduate students. Finally, Benzene now hosts an undergraduate lab tour to expose undergraduates to research opportunities at the university. Past Lecturers: 2012: Harry B. Gray, California Institute of Technology ("Benzene Lecture") 2013: Vy M. Dong, University of California, Irvine ("Benzene Lecture") 2014: Jonas Peters, California Institute of Technology 2015: Peter Wolczanski, Cornell University 2016: Daniel Mindiola, University of Pennsylvania 2017: Martin Karplus, Harvard University (2013 Nobel Prize Laureate in Chemistry) 2018: Charles Lieber, Harvard University 2019: Richard Schrock, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2005 Nobel Prize Laureate in Chemistry) 2020: Moungi Bawendi, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023 Nobel Prize Laureate in Chemistry) 2021: Joanna Aizenberg, Harvard University 2023: Omar Farha, Northwestern 2024: Zhenan Bao, Stanford

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Mondays/ 6:00-7:00PM CST/ Jones Rm. 108 [Key Access Necessary]

name: Chess Club
description_preview: Chess club provides an open and casual environment where anyone can play anyone on Tuesday nights. We also sponsor our members to compete in tournaments, teach at a local CPS school, and more. No experience level requirement. Join: tinyurl.com/y25h25re
full_description: We meet once a week, Tuesday 8pm in Cox Lounge (Basement of Stuart Hall) https://www.facebook.com/groups/638162799532735/ Discord: https://discord.gg/24wWNVxtCB https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Agov3MmZEnrT6fGOGoK_cSJJJF5LfzWKPduV187zvy4/edit?fbclid=IwAR0KTXAR29R7ZbKPqQxGJKOcCGxxygovwz6N8LqVmlpEnidOViRcurPqyG0

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Wednesday  / 8:00 -- 10:30 pm Central / TBA in fb group

name: Chicago Debate Society
description_preview: The Chicago Debate Society is University of Chicago's competitive parliamentary debate team. CDS competes in the American and British Parliamentary debate circuits while promoting discourse on campus through public debates.
full_description: The Chicago Debate Society is the University of Chicago's debate team. We're a registered academic organization that competes in theAmerican Parliamentary Debate Association (APDA)circuit as well as inBritish Parliamentary (BP) Debate. As one of the oldest student organizations at the University, we play an important role in stimulating debate on campus. Our weekly meetings consist of practice rounds, drills, and seminars that teach debate style and argumentation. We send teams to tournaments almost every weekend throughout the school year. We choose not to have a selective application process; there areno cuts. Still, we areone of the most competitively successful teamson the league! Last school year, we ended the APDA season as thebest debate team in the country! If you are interested in joining CDS, sign up for our email list for updates! Visitwww.chicagodebatesociety.org/join

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Wednesdays 6-7PM, Thursdays 6-7PM, Sundays 2-3PM in Cobb Hall. Room numbers communicated in team emails.

name: Chicago Economics Forum
description_preview: The Chicago Economics Forum aims to bring economics into dialogue with diverse perspectives from peer disciplines, business, and technology to explore contemporary topics from globalization to environmental regulation.
full_description: The Chicago Economics Forum aims to bring economics into dialogue with diverse perspectives from peer disciplines, business, and technology to explore contemporary topics. The CEF consists of several cohorts for Finance, Consulting, Academia, and Behavioral Economics that specialize in peer mentorship, event organization, recruiting and job assistance, as well as research.

name: Chicago Italian Appreciation Organization
description_preview: This organization aims to promote Italian culture on campus and to provide a forum for students interested in Italian studies in which they can share their ideas. Knowing Italian is not necessary, but a love for the culture is!
full_description: The Chicago Italian Appreciation Organization aims to provide a space on campus for students to engage with Italian culture. Some of our events include game nights, where we learn Italian card games, movie nights, and family dinners. In the past, we have taken part in cooking competitions and provided ingredients and recipes to members so that we can cook together virtually. We also plan on leading trips to Italian restaurants, cafes, shows, festivals and other cultural locations and events throughout Chicago; organizing tasting events for Italian food and drink; organizing meetup-style events where students can practice their Italian and discuss Italian culture; screening Italian films. Many of our events will be eligible for cultural activity credit with classes in the Italian department.

name: Chicago Journal of Foreign Policy
description_preview: Student-run undergraduate review, focusing on foreign policy and foreign affairs.

name: Chicago Journal of Sociology
description_preview: The Chicago Journal of Sociology seeks to publish high-quality sociological research papers written by undergraduates, from the University of Chicago and other Chicago-based universities; the Journal publishes an annual volume of edited B.A. theses.
full_description: The Chicago Journal of Sociology seeks to publish high-quality sociological research papers written by undergraduates, from the University of Chicago and other Chicago-based universities; the Journal publishes an annual volume of edited B.A. theses. Additionally, the Journal seeks to provide UChicago undergraduates who are interested in sociology with a social space and resources and skills for their academic and professional careers.

description_preview: The Chicago Justice Initiative is an organization created to educate University of Chicago students about social justice issues that relate to UChicago students and the broader Chicago community.
full_description: The Chicago Justice Initiative is the overarching RSO for two groups: #CareNotCops (#CNC) and UChicago Against Displacement (UCAD). #CNC campaigns to abolish campus police and advocates addressing harm through nonpunitive measures. UCAD works with community residents to fight displacement and halt campus expansions into surrounding Black neighborhoods. Both groups have a long history of organizing with South Side communities and organizations, such as fighting for the Trauma Center, supporting the Community Benefits Agreement ordinance, and allying with Defund CPD.

name: Chicago Linguistic Society
description_preview: CLS coordinates academic and social events for linguistics department members and affiliates. In addition, the Society organizes a yearly conference, with a history of almost 60 years.
full_description: CLS coordinates academic and social events for linguistics department members and affiliates. In addition, the Society organizes a yearly conference, with a history of almost 60 years.

name: Chicago Raas Team
description_preview: Chicago Raas is a competitive dance team at the University of Chicago. Raas is a very energetic and lively Indian folk dance from the state of Gujarat, typically performed in a folk setting.
full_description: Chicago Raas welcomes all students and staff to join us in spreading a love for raas dance, cultural awareness, and involvement in the community! We welcome dancers from all backgrounds and embrace diversity in all forms. Chicago Raas won the Outstanding New Recognized Student Organization Award in 2009 for exceeding expectations in contributing to student life and the campus community. Chicago Raas won second place at the annual inter-dance RSO competition Where Fun Comes to Dance in 2013. Chicago Raas was awarded first place at the annual inter-dance RSO competition Where Fun Comes to Dance in 2014. Chicago Raas was awarded first place at the annual inter-dance RSO competition Where Fun Comes to Dance in 2015. Chicago Raas was awarded second place at the annual inter-dance RSO competition Where Fun Comes to Dance in 2016. Chicago Raas was awarded third place at the annual inter-dance RSO competition Where Fun Comes to Dance in 2017. Chicago Raas was awarded second place at the annual inter-dance RSO competition Where Fun Comes to Dance in 2018.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Sunday 2:00-3:30pm; Monday 9-10:30; Ida Noyes Dance Room

name: Chicago Shady Dealer
description_preview: The only intentional humor publication of the University of Chicago, the Shady Dealer provides our campus and community with its fair share of satirical news and humorous writing.
full_description: The Shady Dealer is a satire and humor news magazine (the only one on campus!). We publish fake news and social commentary. We publish 3 issues per quarter for a total of 9 issues each academic year, along with special projects and stunts and online-only content. There are opportunities for students to be involved with writing, editing, layout, and all other aspects of running a publication, but our main goal is absurdity and hilarity!

name: Chicago Street Medicine
description_preview: Chicago Street Medicine's mission is to improve the health and well-being of people who are experiencing unsheltered homelessness on the South Side of Chicago.
full_description: Chicago Street Medicine aims to improve the health and well-being of people who are experiencing unsheltered homelessness. Our approach is two-fold: first, we go on street runs, providing basic medical care, resources, and connections to social services; and second, we conduct research on and work to educate the community about issues that disproportionately affect the health of the homeless.

name: Chicago Studies
description_preview: Chicago Studies engages the intellectual, creative, and civic energies of University of Chicago undergraduates in the life of the diverse communities that make up our world-class city.
full_description: Chicago Studies is a partnership betweenThe Collegeand theOffice of Civic Engagement.  We sponsor events, provide advising, and offer resources that empower members of the University community to discover, study, engage with, and ultimately impact the diverse communities that make up our world-class city. Chicago Studies programming includesongoing events; promotion and sponsorship ofChicago-focused classes, including theChicago Studies Quarter;microgrants for facultyand students; resources to promote scholarship on Chicago, including ourundergraduate journaland our"Engage Chicago Through Research" data portal; and theChicago Studies Certificate Program, which provides advising, support, and transcript-level recognition to undergraduates wishing to integrate their academic inquiry with positive impact in the city. Staffing for Chicago Studies is provided byUniversity Community Service Center (UCSC)and theProgram on the Global Environment, home of the Environmental and Urban Studies Major.

name: Chicago Swing Dance Society
description_preview: The Chicago Swing Dance Society is dedicated to teaching and promoting swing dancing to all, and regularly organizes free lessons and social dances for the UChicago and wider Chicagoland community. Contact us through our facebook or instagram!

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Mondays, Fridays, 7:30pm - 11pm, Ida Noyes Hall, Weekly as room allocations allow.

name: China and Beyond
description_preview: China and Beyond aims to create a close academic community to discuss China-related issues and help raise awareness about UChicago in China.
full_description:
China and Beyond is dedicated to creating an open and close community on campus to discuss China-related issues, including but not limited to culture, art, and economy. We reach
 this goal mainly by organizing themed seminars to invite experts from different fields to share their views. We also hold study breaks to watch classic Chinese movies. In addition, in order to help more Chinese high school students learn about the University
 of Chicago and studying in an American university in general, we have a winter quarter cultural exchange program that brings Chinese students to campus and gives them a taste of college life. New initiatives are currently underway to broaden the audience to
 a larger population of Chinese students with tools of video calls.

name: Chinese Student Christian Fellowship
description_preview: We welcome Chinese students and scholars at University of Chicago as well as local Chinese to join us for bible study and sharing our experience in Lord, and help them settle down in Hyde Park area.
full_description: For more information, please check out our website athttps://sites.google.com/view/uchicagoccf/home?pli=1.

name: Chinese Students and Scholars Association
description_preview: We are a community for fellow Chinese students and scholars, striving to offer assistance and facilitate communication. At the same time, we serve as a bridge between the Chinese and other communities of the University to promote Chinese culture.
full_description: We are a community for fellow Chinese students and scholars, providing opportunities to improve communication, build friendship, and pursue academic and professional advancement. At the same time, we serve as a bridge between the Chinese and other communities of the University to promote Chinese culture and facilitate multicultural understanding. We organize several popular events each year, including the Spring Festival Gala and the Mid-Autumn Celebration.

name: Chinese Undergraduate Students Association
description_preview: UChicago CUSA (Chinese Undergraduate Students Association) is one of the University’s largest cultural-interest communities and seeks to spread the richness of Chinese culture across campus through social events, shows, film, and food.
full_description: UChicago CUSA (Chinese Undergraduate Students Association) is one of the University’s largest cultural-interest communities and seeks to spread the richness of Chinese culture through social events, shows, film, and food. Its diverse membership includes International Chinese, Chinese Americans, and anyone interested in Chinese culture. CUSA seeks to build a cultural community both on campus and across the Chicago metro area, and often hosts events in conjunction with other universities.

name: Christians on Campus
description_preview: We are a Christian RSO who seeks to help students know Christ and grow in the Christian faith both individually and with one another at UChicago. We hold weekly Bible studies and fellowship with families in the community. Come and join us!

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Bible Studies (Mondays 7:30 pm at Harper 148), Friday Meetings (see emails!)

name: Classical Lecture Society
description_preview: Every year the Classical Lecture Society brings two guest speakers to our campus to discuss various topics in the study of the classics.
full_description: We are a graduate student organization based in the Classics Department. Every year, the graduate students of the department nominate and vote on speakers; the leading two vote getters are invited to campus to give a lecture and hold a seminar. We try to focus on scholars who are an area of expertise that isn't already covered by faculty here at Chicago.

name: College Bowl Team
description_preview: College Bowl, also known as quiz bowl, is an academic team competition. We compete against other college teams from around the U.S. (and the world) on questions that test knowledge of history, science, literature, arts, and beyond.
full_description: College Bowl, also known as quiz bowl, is an academic team competition. We compete against other college teams from around the U.S. (and the world) on questions that test knowledge of history, science, literature, arts, and beyond. Subscribe to ourlistservwhere practices and events are announced, or visit ourwebsite.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Mondays and Thursdays 7-9pm. Harper 135 & Harper 151 on Monday; Harper 102 & Harper 135 on Thursday

name: College Council
description_preview: The undergraduate representative council of Student Government.
full_description: The College Council is a representative council of Undergraduate Student Government that serves the undergraduate population.  It consists of 21 representative members—five first-year students, five second-year students, five third-year students, five students in their fourth-year or beyond, as well as a Chair.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website::
Student Government at the University of Chicago
