name: College Fed Challenge Team
description_preview: Fed Challenge participants research the economy, formulate a monetary policy proposal, and compete against other colleges by presenting/defending their proposal to economists at their regional Federal Reserve Bank.
full_description: The Federal Reserve Challenge is an educational competition that teaches participants to think critically about U.S. monetary policy. Students research the economy, formulate a policy proposal, and compete against other colleges by presenting/defending their proposal to economists at their regional Federal Reserve Bank. This year we will also be expanding to compete in the FDIC Academic Challenge and Fiscal Challenge.

name: College Republicans
description_preview: The UChicago Republicans represent an array of students who passionately advocate for individual liberty and government accountability while engaging the campus body in political discourse and substantive programming.
full_description: College Republicans is the place on campus where conservative, libertarian, center-right, and otherwise independently-minded individuals meet not only to discuss current events but also to shape them. Whether it is meeting with some of the movers and shakers in politics or working with student-run media outlets like The Chicago Thinker, our members have been able to see their political influence firsthand. We work hard to make an impact, but we also have fun at events like bowling and political trivia.

name: Colombians at UChicago
description_preview: Colombian students at The University of Chicago
full_description: Colombians at Chicago is an organization that seeks to create a network of Colombians studying at The University of Chicago and develop events that will strengthen our community and raise awareness about our country’s opportunities and issues. These events seek to promote long-lasting relationships between students and alumni, and the country’s present and future academics and leaders, who intend to understand better the country’s context and how to achieve better economic and social development.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: One quarterly meeting TBD every month

name: Comer Tutors
description_preview: Student tutors that provide academic services at the University of Chicago Comer Children's Hospital with the goal of promoting learning and helping with homework while patients are unable to attend school.
full_description: We seek to organize and train tutors who will provide academic services to inpatients at the University of Chicago Comer Children's Hospital. During their stay at the hospital, school-age patients have limited or no access to academic resources for weeks and months at a time. Through tutoring, we aim to keep patients at pace with their assigned schoolwork so that they can continue to achieve academically when they do return to school. We will be recruiting new volunteers in the Winter 2025 quarter. Please email tutorscomer@gmail.com with your name and year if you would like to be added to our interest list.Our recruitment process involves a written application followed by an interview for selected applicants.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Monthly, time decided each quarter. Regenstein Library

name: Commedia dell'Arte
description_preview: UChicago Commedia is a theatrical ensemble committed to practicing and sharing the art of Commedia dell'Arte. Commedia is a sixteenth-century art form hailing from Italy that marries physical theater, improvisation, mask work, and slapstick.
full_description: The purpose of this organization shall be to preserve and practice the art of Commedia on campus and to share it with the UChicago community. Commedia is a sixteenth-century art form hailing from Italia that marries physical theater, improvisation, mask work, song, dance, and slapstick humor.  It is the root of many of today’s popular art forms, such as ballet, opera, pantomime, and sketch comedy.  We collaborate in the process of bringing this unique tradition into today’s world with unbridled enjoyment. We believe in the fundamental power of the ensemble as an artistic unit. Working as an ensemble, where relationships, not individuals, define the audience’s focus, helps us to create a compelling performance and also a community. When Commedia casts its ensemble, the Attori Senza Paura, we cast them for a year, as we feel a year is necessary to engender the type of familiarity needed to have a strong group of actors. Commedia approaches acting from a physical perspective. We connect to our characters emotionally by literally embodying them, and letting the mental aspect of the performance flow from this base. In other words, we love gestures. Commedia takes the art of not taking oneself seriously extremely seriously. Commedia understands that the human condition is often found in its extremes: characters fighting over a cookie as though it is a matter of life or death. We hope to convey this message to the UChicago populace.

name: Community Health Initiative
description_preview: To provide for the medical care and overall wellness of the residents of Maria Shelter, a transitional shelter for women and children, in Englewood, and as well as for the patients at the Community Health Clinic in West Town.
full_description: The Maria Shelter Clinic is the core program of the Community Health Initiative. During each clinic, eight to fourteen patients are seen, both adult and pediatric, all of whom are residents of Maria Shelter and looking to find a home and/or employment. Since many do not have insurance, the clinic ensures access to primary care and psychiatric care. However, we acknowledge that health is multi-faceted. Thus, around 3-4 times a month, we work to provide wellness, reflection, and educational events at the shelter. These events are meant to bring the community together, build trust between students and residents, and enrich residents’ understanding of health and wellness.

name: Council On University Programming
description_preview: The Council on University Programming is a student-run board providing UChicago with large-scale entertainment. We oversee the majority of UChicago traditions, such as Kuvia, Snowball, and Summer Breeze.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Changes quarterly, currently Thursdays 7pm in Reg Room 303

name: Crew
description_preview: UChicago Crew competes nationally and internationally in collegiate regattas.  Founded in 1976, we are the largest sports club on campus.  Visit our website or Facebook page to stay updated on our events and races!
full_description: The University of Chicago Crew competes nationally and internationally in collegiate regattas.  Founded in 1976, we are one of the largest sport clubs on campus.  Our men's and women's programs are administered by a coed Executive Board. We practice all year and accept new members in the fall and winter.  Visit our website or Facebook page to stay updated on our events and races!

name: Cricket Club
description_preview:
Players of all skill levels are welcome to join! 

To get updates, join the facebook group at www.facebook.com/groups/uchicagocricket or the WhatsApp group (DM the president!)
full_description: The list host is at lists.uchicago.edu and is called cricinfo! That said, we conduct most of our activity via WhatsApp or Facebook...

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Henry Crown Field House, Upper Level -- FRI & SAT (6-8pm)

name: Crime & Justice Policy Association
description_preview: CJPA is a hub through which University of Chicago students and the greater Chicago community can educate ourselves and others about issues of crime, public safety, drug policy, violence prevention, and other issues of criminal justice.
full_description: The Crime & Justice Policy Association (CJPA) is a hub and platform through which University of Chicago students and the greater Chicago community can educate ourselves and others about issues of crime, criminal justice, public safety, drug policy, violence prevention, and other related areas of public policy. By facilitating dialogue and raising awareness, we also hope to serve as a meaningful community amplifier and advocate for effective policy solutions to these issues.

name: Critical Understanding of Liturgies and Traditions
description_preview: Spring 2024 New RSO

name: CS Student Activities Council
description_preview: A group to bring together all of UChicago's students interested in tech.
full_description: The CS Student Activities Council) is an RSO (Registered Student Organization) at the University of Chicago. To put it simply, our group revolves around learning and creating awesome stuff using technology; we love tinkering and learning about all sorts of technology. We serve as an umbrella organization for all the CS-related tech organizations on campus. This includesACM-W, CompileHer, andUncommon Hacks. More information on each organization with links will be posted soon, but you can find them all on Facebook. In addition to comprising these four organizations, the CS SAC also hosts weekly Hack Nights throughout the year.Hack Nightsare informal social events on Friday nights, where anyone interested in technology can hang out and enjoy some free pizza and soda. You do not need to work on any specific project or come share anything in particular; many students just come to hang out with their fellow hackers. Membership has no formal requirements. Basically, if you’re in ourFacebook groupor attend any of our events, you can consider yourself a member of the group.

name: Cup of Theater
description_preview: Cup of Theater is a space for students to participate in more experimental and less regulated theater productions and other role-playing entertainment than those of University Theater.
full_description: Cup of Theateris a Registered Student Organization at the University of Chicago originally founded in 2004 as the Classical Entertainment Society. Since its original inception it has evolved to become a space for students to participate in more experimental and less regulated theater productions than those of University Theater. MISSION: TO PRODUCE innovative and experimental theater productions of all shapes and forms in a box theater environment. TO COLLABORATE with the broader University of Chicago and Hyde Park communities to re-engage with our performative work and to forge new bonds through storytelling. TO ENGAGE and encourage students of various backgrounds and experiences. TO ENTERTAIN.

name: Dance Council
description_preview: The University of Chicago Dance Council is a co-curricular program with Theater and Performance Studies involving all existing dance RSOs on campus.
full_description: The University of Chicago Dance Council is a co-curricular program with Theater and Performance Studies (TAPS) involving all existing dance RSOs on campus. Its purpose is threefold: 1) To provide resources, support, performance opportunities, and publicity for dance RSOs and the general dance community 2) To advance the presence and accessibility of dance on campus by serving as a liaison between the dance student body and the TAPS administration 3) To serve as a body for all dance RSOs to come together and collectively elevate the status and quality of dance here at the University of Chicago. Additionally, Dance Council conducts meetings at least twice a quarter, bringing together representatives from all dance RSOs to address each RSO's individual needs and concerns, as well as collectively develop dance programming.

name: Dear Asian Youth
description_preview: The UChicago chapter of Dear Asian Youth seeks to empower APIDA (Asian Pacific Islander Desi American) youth, increase overall awareness about APIDA issues and culture, and promote political engagement and intersectional activism.
full_description: Welcome to the UChicago chapter of Dear Asian Youth (DAY)! DAY is an international non-partisan, youth-led non-profit and literary magazine centering around APIDA voices. The UChicago chapter of DAY seeks to empower APIDA (Asian Pacific Islander Desi American) youth, increase overall awareness about APIDA issues and culture, and promote political engagement and intersectional activism among the APIDA community and beyond.

description_preview: Defenders is an organization at the Law School. Our goal is to help students start their legal careers as public defenders. To that end, we host events to connect students with public defenders and highlight issues within the criminal justice system.
full_description: Defenders is a law school student organization dedicated to creating a community of future public defenders, assisting them with their professional development and employment searches by providing networking opportunities, training, and online resources, and educating the student body about the role of public defenders in the criminal justice system.

name: Delta Sigma Pi Professional Business Fraternity- Alpha Psi Chapter
description_preview: Delta Sigma Pi promotes the study of business in UChicago's theoretical academic environment. We are striving to build a co-ed community based on lifelong professional fulfillment, a lasting commitment to service, and successful personal relationships.
full_description: The Alpha Psi Chapter of Delta Sigma Pi is a member of the national Delta Sigma Pi Professional Business Fraternity, and our mission is embodied by the organization’s purpose: “Delta Sigma Pi is a professional fraternity organized to foster the study of business in universities; to encourage scholarship, social activity and the association of students for their mutual advancement by research and practice; to promote closer affiliation between the commercial world and students of commerce, and to further a higher standard of commercial ethics and culture and the civic and commercial welfare of the community.”

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website::
Delta Sigma Pi Professional Business Fraternity
https://www.deltasigmapi.org

name: Derivatives Group
description_preview: Derivatives Group (Quant) Trading is dedicated to educating its members on the public financial markets, with a focus on financial derivatives, in order to prepare them for academic research and careers in industry.
full_description: Derivatives Group (Quant) Trading is dedicated to educating its members on the financial markets, with a focus on financial derivatives, in order to prepare them for academic research and careers in industry. By providing historical context and a rigorous, theory-focused learning program through curriculum and mentorship, our organization will enable its members to produce research on a financial derivatives related topic as a part of the RSO.

name: Derivatives of Data Science
description_preview: We explore the myriad applications of data science in economics, mathematics, biology, social sciences, and many more. We host prestigious guest speakers from industry and academia alike, facilitating productive engagement for our members.

name: Dirt Red Brass Band
description_preview: New Orleans-style brass band. Look for us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/UChicagos-Dirt-Red-Brass-Band/393794394033909
full_description: We've been called everything from "the least controversial RSO on campus" to "the most high-octane fun." We’ve played with Vulfpeck, for the likes of Bernie Sanders, and we’re known to break floors.  UChicago’s funkiest jazz/funk/pop brass band has existed on campus for the last 12 years, and we perform at events both on campus and in Chicago at large. Come groove with us!

name: Documentary Films
description_preview: Doc Films screens new and repertory films every day of the school year and four days a week in the summer. We aim to bring a wide variety of film to campus for the University community as well as the general public.
full_description: NOTE: Blueprint is for Doc Films administrative work. To learn how to volunteer, visitdocfilms.org/volunteer. Since its inception in 1932, the Documentary Films group had a long-standing commitment in providing a wide variety of films to the University of Chicago community, Hyde Park, and Chicago at large, serving as both an educational and entertainment resource. At the heart of Doc’s mission is the students’ attempt to reach anyone and everyone --- from film buffs to the everyday moviegoer. Our organization involves dozens of devoted volunteers and programmers from both outside and within the University community, bringing the magic of unparalleled cinema to Hyde Park.

name: DoGS Lunch
description_preview: This organization provides a venue for constructive interaction amongst students in disciplines within the geophysical sciences and related subjects. Lunch-time meetings provide an audience for graduate student from Geosci to present their research.
full_description: The purpose of this organization shall be to provide a venue for constructive interaction amongst students in disciplines within the geophysical sciences and related subjects. The lunch-time meetings shall provide an audience for randomly selected graduate student presenters from the Department of the Geophysical Sciences to present their research. Each week, a 45 min presentation will be given by a different graduate student, until all have presented, providing a venue for the graduate students to practice speaking, to get to know each other, and for the rest of the interested members to experience a wide range of geophysical science topics. Non-graduate student members shall not be required to present, but can present their if they so desire on a volunteer basis. Undergraduates interested in majoring or minoring in the geophysical sciences, or doing graduate work in the geophysical sciences, are especially encouraged to attend.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website:: Department of the Geophysical Sciences https://geosci.uchicago.edu/

name: East African Student Association
description_preview: The East African Student Association aims to bring together East African students on campus in addition to celebrating and sharing a shared background and culture.

name: Eckhart Consulting
description_preview: Since 2002, Eckhart Consulting has advised over 150 of the world's leading corporations, nonprofits, startups, and civic institutions. Collaborating closely with top-tier professionals and executives, EC consultants foster strategic change and creativity
full_description: Eckhart Consulting is a strategy and management consulting group at the University of Chicago. Since our founding in 2002, EC has advised a diverse set of corporate, nonprofit, startup, and civic clients. Working with professionals from top-tier consulting firms, EC consultants aim to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of clients' operations. Past clients include Amazon, Uber, United Airlines, the United Nations, and McDonald's.

name: Edge Entrepreneurship
description_preview: Edge is the undergraduate organization for entrepreneurship at UChicago.
full_description: Theory and practice shouldn’t be mutually exclusive. Edge is the undergraduate organization for entrepreneurship at UChicago. We work to offer 3 distinct elements to all students who interact with us: Exposure Edge events are hosted with some of the most innovative organizations, businesses, startups, and individuals around. Gain exposure or simply attend an event. Experience Edge meets weekly to facilitate discourse about entrepreneurship and build up the entrepreneurial community on campus. Our meetings are a mix of startup work, events, guest speakers, networking, workshops, and treks. Have any questions? Check out our website atwww.uchicagoedge.comand feel free to email us at uchicagoedge@gmail.com if you have any questions.

name: Edmund Burke Society
description_preview: The purpose of the Edmund Burke Society shall be to provide a forum at the University of Chicago for conservative political debate and literary discussion.
full_description: The Edmund Burke Society hosts parliamentary-style debates where students consider and argue on important political and social issues.

name: Emergency Medical Services
description_preview: The University of Chicago Emergency Medical Service (UCEMS) is dedicated to providing EMR and EMT-level stand-by medical response at campus events and training members of the campus and community to provide life saving care through CPR and EMT courses.
full_description: The University of Chicago Emergency Medical Services (UCEMS) is a student-driven organization committed to providing exceptional emergency medical care and fostering a culture of preparedness within the University community. Our mission is to train, certify, and deploy Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs) who operate within the scope of practice, ensuring the safety and well-being of individuals at various campus events and activities. UCEMS is dedicated to continuous improvement, collaboration with medical professionals, and contributing to the broader emergency medical education. Currently, UCEMS runs two training courses, provides opportunities for club members to practice emergency medicine by providing first aid assistance at intramural sports (facilitated through Intramural Director Matthew Fox), and puts on community building events to increase club membership and spread awareness of crucial life-saving skills (CPR, Stop the Bleed). First, we engage with the broader student community by offering an EMR (Emergency Medical Responders) course to provide interested students with a lower commitment, quarter-long course to learn the basics of emergency medicine and gain CPR licenses. Students who have taken our EMR course have expressed an interest in continuing to take an more intensive EMT course to obtain a higher level licensure which they can use to staff with UCEMS and access volunteer and career opportunities with emergency medical organizations across Chicago. EMRs and EMTs who have passed their respective classes are invited to join our Responder in Training (RIT) course, which consists of a 3 week review of unit procedures and scenario practice, before undergoing advancement testing to formally join UCEMS as a practicing responder. Practicing responders staff intramural sports events in teams of two, providing invaluable first aid supplies and on scene medical treatment for any injuries. Practicing responders also attend weekly drill sessions, which are community bonding events through which the UCEMS Quality Improvement Officer reviews or introduces new skills to the unit. UCEMS is also dedicated to promoting basic first aid and health literacy among our community. Every year, UCEMS leads a SPLASH course to certify local high school students in CPR. We also host quarterly open drills, open to all, in which unit members demonstrate skills such as splinting broken bones, controlling bleeding, or doing basic medical assessments, to encourage others to become involved in UCEMS and pursue an emergency medicine prehospital license. Within the unit, we host quarterly social events designed to connect students interested in pursuing medical careers to form a support network. Finally, we periodically invite our faculty club advisor (Dr. Willard Sharp of UCMed) and Pritzker Medical School students to speak at drill meetings to allow club members to learn about various careers in medicine. We look forward to continuing these professional development opportunities next year by connecting students with shadowing opportunities with emergency medicine physicians and allowing responders to gain more patient experience by operating at the EMT level.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website:: National Collegiate Emergency Medical Services Foundation (NCEMSF)  http://www.ncemsf.org

name: Engineering Society
description_preview: An RSO for students interested in building things. Each quarter we host workshops, guest speakers, competitions, and projects, including rockets, electronics/robotics, and 3D printing, to give students fun ways to spend time and build engineering skills.
full_description: We are an Engineering RSO that has been operating since 2010. The Engineering Society serves the UChicago community regardless of academic year or major providing large-scale Engineering project opportunities, free Engineering workshops, social events, and professional development events.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Meetings are Irregular - Stay up to date with the Engineering Society Email list, facebook or instagram for upcoming events.

name: ENoK - Empowerment/Emancipation of North Koreans
description_preview: We are the only on-campus human rights advocacy group for North Korean defectors residing in the US. We provide 1-to-1 mentoring and tutoring services to these North Korean students, classes ranging from English, Music, to even Yoga.
full_description: We are the only on-campus human rights advocacy group for North Korean defectors residing in the US. We provide 1-to-1 mentoring and tutoring services to these North Korean students, classes ranging from English, Music, to even Yoga. No Korean language skills are required for tutors, and we encourage the defector students to have as wide a range of experiences as possible with a diverse volunteer pool.

name: Environmental Justice Task Force
description_preview: We are a student power organization committed to achieving social and ecological justice. We understand that this goal is deeply tied to questions of racial, economic, and gender justice, and is therefore a fundamentally political challenge.
full_description: We are a student power organization committed to advocating for achieving social and ecological justice. We understand that this goal is deeply tied to liberation from racial capitalism, and is therefore a fundamentally political challenge, more so than a technological one. EJTF organizes and supports campaigns to place pressure on the University, elected officials, and community leaders to take action on climate and environmental injustices. We are currently focused on getting UChicago to divest its endowment from fossil fuels and establish financial transparency and community accountability measures (find out more at uchicagodivest.com). We have also been involved in supporting community organizations’ work, such as on banning toxic chemicals like petcoke and manganese in Chicago, the campaign against General Iron on the southeast side, and the Illinois Clean Jobs Coalition’s clean and affordable buildings campaign. Follow us on Instagram @ej_taskforce and @divestuchicago!

name: Environmental Law Society
description_preview: ELS educates law students, as well as other members of the University of Chicago (UChicago) community and general public, about topics and careers in environmental law and works to promote sustainability at the Law School.

name: Environmental Research Group
description_preview: The Environmental Research Group is an undergraduate think tank devoted to interfacing science and social good to create sustainable change in Chicago through applicable, data-driven modeling, policy research and community outreach.
full_description: The Environmental Research Group is an undergraduate science and policy think tank devoted to interfacing science and social good to create sustainable change in Chicago through applicable, data-driven modeling. Science can oftentimes be void of application to the real world. So, the ERG was created to help build the bridge between data-driven solutions and real-world impact. Our group is split into 3 distinct working groups. The Data Analysis working group quality controls, performs statistical analyses on, and produces engaging graphics of our project data sets. The Policy working group synthesizes the output from the Data Analysis working group with their own social science research to produce novel policy solutions to environmental and urban problems. Finally, the Community Outreach working group takes all these results and works with community leaders to hone our solutions towards a feasible, sustainable product that can be implemented in the Chicago community. The ERG also runs the Intercollegiate Sustainability Alliance with 4 other Chicago colleges and helped to start the UChicago Environmental Alliance, a unified group of all environmental RSOs on campus.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website:: Not affiliated with any parent/national/international organization.

name: Equestria
description_preview: Equestria is an RSO that hosts horseback riding lessons off campus and is open to all members of the UChicago community. Riders of all ages and experience levels are welcome!
full_description: Equestria is UChicago’s only horse-oriented RSO and is open to anyone in the UChicago community - our members include undergrads, graduate students, alumni, and more. We are purely recreational; we do not compete at any shows and your level of participation is entirely up to you. We have anywhere from 1-3 riding opportunities per week. These lessons usually last around 4-5 hours round trip and include the drive to and from campus as well as grooming and caring for the horses. Riders of all levels are welcome to participate. Please note that students are responsible for paying part of the lesson fee but the club will cover travel costs. If you are interested in joining, please email us for more information about the club!

name: Ethics Bowl
description_preview: We teach, learn, and practice the procedures of competitive Ethics Bowl—including philosophical and ethical terminology, public speaking skills, deep and critical thinking for complex issues, and building strong arguments in collaboration with others.
full_description: Welcome to the University of Chicago's Ethics Bowl Team! We teach, learn, and practice the procedures of competitive Ethics Bowl. Members will become familiar with philosophical and ethical terminology, improve their public speaking, learn how to think deeply and critically about complex issues,and practice building strong arguments in collaboration with others—all skills that would be developed during practices and when we host and/or compete in competitions between UChicago teams, and other schools as well.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Tuesdays: 7:00 - 9:00 p.m. - Harper 148 & Thursdays: 7:00 - 9:00 p.m. - Harper 104
additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website::
Association For Practical and Professional Ethics Intercollegiate Ethics Bowl
https://www.appe-ethics.org/appe-ieb-

name: Euphony Journal
description_preview: Euphony Journal is a biannual literary journal dedicated to publishing the finest work by current writers, both accomplished and aspiring.
full_description: Founded in the spring of 2000, Euphony is a student-run semiannual literary journal at The University of Chicago that publishes the poetry and prose of both accomplished and aspiring writers from around the world and within the University community. We release our print issues in the winter and spring, in addition to publishing exclusive online writing year-round.

name: EX Crew
description_preview: EX Crew is a competitive choreography group formed in 2009 with the hope of connecting with and enriching the dance community at UChicago, in Hyde Park, and in the city of Chicago. The crew performs and competes at various on-campus and Chicago events.
full_description: Formed in 2009, EX Crew is a competitive choreography group that aims to build a hip hop presence at UChicago, connect with the dance community in the greater Chicago area, foster new friendships, and create a fun and inviting space where dancers can express their creative talents. While EX Crew is a primarily hip hop-centric group, they also incorporate a multitude of dance styles into their choreography to create innovative, concept-forward sets.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Mondays 9-11pm, Wednesdays 7-9pm, and Saturdays 5-7pm, in Bartlett Arts Rehearsal Space

name: Federalist Society
description_preview: The Federalist Society is a group dedicated to freedom, the separation of governmental powers is central to our Constitution, and with the belief that it is the province and duty of the judiciary to say what the law is, not what is should be.
full_description: The Federalist Society is a group of libertarians and conservatives interested in the current state of the legal order. The Society was founded on the principles that the state exists to preserve freedom, that the separation of governmental powers is central to our Constitution, and that it is the province and duty of the judiciary to say what the law is, not what it should be. Through its activities, the Society seeks to promote an awareness of these principles and to further their application. The Federalist Society was formed in 1982 by law students at the University of Chicago, Yale and Harvard. Justice Antonin Scalia, then a professor at the Law School, helped organize the University of Chicago Law School chapter of the Federalist Society. Each year, we bring speakers to the Law School for lectures and debates in an effort to open and to balance the debate on legal issues. Whenever possible, the Society invites speakers on both sides of the issue in order to present a balanced discussion on the topic.

name: Fellowship of Christian Athletes
description_preview: FCA seeks to provide fellowship for Christians across the UChicago campus through the platform of sports and to invite others to engage in informal dialogue about Christ and the Gospel through weekly meetings and outreach events.
full_description: FCA seeks to provide fellowship for Christians across the UChicago campus through the platform of sports and to invite others to engage in informal dialogue about Christ and the Gospel through weekly meetings and outreach events.

name: Feminist Forum
description_preview: Feminist Forum is a UChicago RSO dedicated to recentralizing feminist discussion on people of marginalized identities and groups. Our goal to uplift the voices of, and provide support for, BIPOC, LGBTQA+, and disabled people within this movement.
full_description: While many feminists are well intentioned, the feminist movement has a long history of prioritizing only some voices and needs - particularly those of white, cisgendered, straight, middle class, thin, able-bodied women. Feminist Forum is a UChicago RSO dedicated to recentralizing feminist discussion on people of marginalized identities and groups. Our goal to uplift the voices of BIPOC, LGBTQA+, and disabled people within this movement and do active work for the women and people of marginalized gender who need the most support. We hold discussion meetings, host professor talks and dinners, and organize events to support the women and people of marginalized genders in our community, here in Hyde Park, and beyond. Our discussion meetings are informal opportunities to talk about media (articles, podcasts, movies, etc) about a given feminist topic. They are an opportunity to take a second to listen and engage with what these communities are saying. Educating oneself by listening to community leaders must always be the first step to activism.

name: Fencing Club
description_preview: A club for both beginners and experienced fencers to practice, have fun, and compete in tournaments against other schools
full_description: No experience required. We provide equipment and instruction, but also welcome experienced fencers from all levels of the university. Dues are $20 per quarter. You must sign a liability waiver. Practices are from 5-7p Mon-Thurs and 4-6p Fri on the Balcony (the top floor) of Henry Crown Field House, and typically consist of one hour of conditioning and drills and one hour of fencing.  The practice schedule is sometimes different for each weapon so please contact us at uofcfencingprez@gmail.com (or on instagram @uchicagofencing) to know specifically when practices are!

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Monday-Thursday 5pm-7pm, Friday 4-6pm @ Henry Crown Field House Balcony

name: Festival of the Arts
description_preview: Festival of the Arts, more dearly known as FOTA, has been a campus tradition since 1963. Throughout the year, FOTA hosts workshops, galleries, and various performance events in celebration of the talent, expression, and diversity of our student artists.
full_description: The mission of FOTA is to promote art and creativity at The University of Chicago by bringing together the diversity of campus -- artists and audiences -- through on-campus events that advocate arts creation and appreciation. FOTA contributes to campus in multiple ways. FOTA fosters a community of artists and individuals who are art-inclined. FOTA unites visual artists with performance artists to create dynamic and unique creations. FOTA hosts events that lend students a platform to express themselves through art. Our annual events include: -Springfest: Weeklong arts festival showcasing student artwork -Sight x Sound: Night of dynamic performances showcasing visual artist and performance artist pairs -Gallery Night: Spotlight of one to two visual artists in a chosen cafe or campus space -FOTA Fellowship: Opportunity for student artists to participate in intimate program with fellow artists

name: Field Hockey
description_preview: Recreational Field Hockey.
full_description: UChicago Field Hockey Club for recreational and competitive play of the sport field hockey.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Friday and Sunday, either at campus south or Stagg

name: Figure Skating
description_preview: UChicago Figure Skating is a sports club that provides students the resources to maintain and advance their pre-existing skills. Members are welcome to join regular group skating sessions and volunteer for the neighbourhood Learn To Skate program.
full_description: UChicago Figure Skating is a sports club that provides interested students the resources to maintain and advance their pre-existing skills. Members are welcome to join regular group skating sessions in Fall and Winter quarters. Club members also volunteer for the neighbourhood Learn To Skate program, teaching young kids aged 3-12 how to figure skate.

name: Fire Escape Films
description_preview: Fire Escape Films is the University of Chicago's only organization for film production and education. Our members learn filmmaking as they participate in our productions, which are entirely written, directed, produced, and created by students.
full_description: Fire Escape Films is the student-run film production organization at the University of Chicago. Our goal is to sustain a community of student filmmakers through the entire film production process. Our members come from all majors and backgrounds, and we do not require any prior experience in order to join. We help directors recruit casts and crews from among the student body, fund their films, give them access to advanced equipment, and cover the fees necessary to submit films to festivals. Fire Escape Films not only produces and showcases original student films but also offers workshops, general meetings, and speaker events about film production. Our website:fireescapefilms.org Email: fecommittee@gmail.com

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Tuesdays 6:30-7:30 PM in Stuart Hall 102 , further information available on Facebook

name: Firebird Magazine
description_preview: Firebird Magazine is the University of Chicago’s premier student-run music publication. Our goal is to bring student-driven music journalism to campus, including interviews with student artists, album reviews, concert reviews, and music history pieces.

name: Folklore Society
description_preview: Founded in the 1950s, the UChicago Folklore Society is dedicated to celebrating folk music, dance, and arts on campus.  Our annual Folk Fest draws hundreds of people to Ida Noyes and Mandel Hall to enjoy concerts, jam sessions, workshops, and more!
full_description: The UChicago Folklore Society is dedicated to celebrating folk music, arts, and dance at the University of Chicago, in Hyde Park, and beyond.  We host regular contra dances, trips to folk events around Chicago and student folk music showcases throughout the school year.  Our largest event is the UChicago Folk Festival.  Now in its 64th year, the Folk Fest brings professional folk artists and folk music lovers from around the city and country (and often beyond) to the Mandel Hall stage for a weekend of concerts, workshops, dancing, singing, jamming, and folk merry-making.  We are proud to continue our long legacy of presenting traditional strains of folk music to large audiences and are always thrilled to bring new genres that we (and our audience) love to our Fests. We also handle all promotion for the festival, hire musicians and vendors, organize a large group of volunteers for the concerts, sell tickets and handle all of the other minutiae that go into a running a two day music festival.

name: Food Recovery Network
description_preview: Food Recovery Network is a service organization dedicated to addressing environmental justice and food insecurity by recovering leftover food on campus for local shelters and community centers.
full_description: Food Recovery Network is a service organization dedicated to addressing environmental justice and food insecurity by recovering leftover food on campus for local shelters and community centers. We recover from the UChicago dining halls, campus cafes, and campus events 4 times a week. We also meet biweekly to discuss food and environmental-justice related topics! Check out our Free Food Watch Instagram page for posts about free food on campus leftover from events or information on food assistance for UChicago students.

name: Food Run Project
description_preview: Food Run Project provides food and resources to Chicago's homeless population. We see value in personal interaction with Chicago's poor, restoring dignity to a group often marginalized by mainstream society.
full_description: Food Run Project was founded in 2002 as a new way to serve Chicago's homeless and working poor. FRP firmly believes that one must experience the homeless face-to-face to truly understand and help the growing problem of homelessness in Chicago. We see value in personal interaction with Chicago's poor, restoring dignity to an often marginalized group. Our goal is two-fold: one, to provide food, clothing, and resources to Chicago's homeless and working poor; and two, to instill a concern for the poor in the lives of college students. By providing opportunities for community service every week in a relaxed, fun environment, FRP has become a UChicago mainstay. By encouraging interaction and respect, FRP members have forged enriching friendships with Chicago's homeless and working poor. Questions: katjae@uchicago.edu

name: French Club
description_preview: A student organization that aims to promote the French language and Francophone cultures, unite Francophiles and Francophones, and stimulate discussion on social, political and cultural issues in the world.
full_description: The University of Chicago French Club offersthree core programs: Weekly MeetingsEach week, the French Club hosts casual meetings that provide a welcoming space to practice French at all levels. Around bread and cheese, members meet fellow francophiles, discuss current French affairs, watch French movies or play games in French in a flexible, non-academic setting. Annual EventsEvery year, the French Club brings the best of French culture to campus with three events open to the entire campus community. Past events have included: Speed-dating in French, Cheese Tasting, Study Abroad Q&A and Crepe Study Break. We are looking to introduce our "Cultural Series" this year, consisting of one major event per quarter, which will focus on one particular Francophone region. We will also offer one major event per quarter that focuses more on practicing French. Speaker SeriesLaunched in 2012, our Speaker Series seeks to foster discussion on a wide breadth of issues in contemporary France. We invite practitioners at the heart of French political and social life to share their experience and provide context surrounding certain "Franco-French" particularities, which can sometimes be baffling from an American perspective. Our first speaker was Fadela Amara, former French junior minister of Urban Policy and founder of the feminist organization Ni Putes Ni Soumises (Neither Whores Nor Submissive) which supported the 2010 ban on burqas in France. Since then, we have hosted events on campus with Julia Kristeva, Frédéric Lefebvre, Henry Laurens, Laurent Fabuis, Dominique de Villepin, Zineb el Razhoui, and Marie-Monique Robin.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Fridays 5:00–6:00 PM; Reynolds Club, Student Activity Center

name: Friends of Washington Park Youth Program
description_preview: Student Volunteers mentor and tutor children from the Washington Park neighborhoods. Done through academic enrichment packages and homework assistance.
full_description: Friends of Washington Park is an RSO that assists children, K-12, with their academics through tutoring services, homework assistance, and other curriculum enrichment supplements. As a volunteer tutor, you'd independently tutor one or two students for the entirety of year -- hopefully while developing a strong relationship with your student(s). While student volunteers' main responsibility is homework assistance, another important aspect is mentorship. Because tutors work with the same students on a regular basis, strong relationships are formed, allowing the tutors to provide social and emotional support for the students in addition to academic support. We meet on Mondays and Wednesdays from 5:30 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. outside the UChicago Bookstore to take a bus to the Chicago Youth Program building in Washington Park. Stop by! Make a difference!

name: Game Design
description_preview: UChicago Game Design is the on campus hub dedicated to creation and discussion of games, both digital and analogue.
full_description: UChicago Game Design is UChicago's home for discussing, learning, and practicing game design. We invite creative minds across campus to engage with both theoretical and practical game design principles, with events ranging from critical analyses to focused design workshops to solo and collaborative development opportunities. We strive to cover a diverse range of design areas and to accommodate every creator, from writers and musicians to graphic artists and programmers. For regular updates, join our listhost or Discord channel! (https://discord.gg/eWfEsJv)

name: Gargoyle Consulting Club
description_preview:
Gargoyle Consulting Club is a platform for PhDs, MDs, JDs, Master's, Post-docs, and Undergrads who are interested in a career in consulting. 
*** Please visit our website and subscribe to our listserv to stay informed of our resources and events.
full_description: Gargoyle Consulting Club is a platform for PhDs, MDs, JDs, Master's, Post-docs, and Undergrads who are interested in a career in consulting. The club hosts a variety of activities throughout the year, all of which fit a recruiting timeline for advanced degrees candidates interested in pursuing consulting careers.

name: Gateway to the Great Outdoors
description_preview: GGO (Gateway to the Great Outdoors) partners with low-income Chicago Public Schools to provide hands-on, inquiry-based environmental and outdoor education, nature-based outings and trips, and year-round mentorship to students.
full_description: GGO partners with low-income public schools (currently in Chicago, IL and St. Louis, MO) to provide extensive environmental, outdoor, and STEAM education. GGO’s curriculum combines hands-on, inquiry-based classroom STEAM instruction, and nature-based outings & overnight trips, with year-round mentorship provided by university students. GGO partners directly with the classroom science teachers to assure that the curriculum augments traditional classroom learning. Each GGO program consists of weekly classroom lessons, monthly outdoor adventures, overnight camping trips each semester, and continuous year-round mentorship. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zr19wl85m14

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Bi-weekly on Mondays at 6:00 pm CT in Harper 104

name: GeneHackers
description_preview: The official UChicago iGEM team.
full_description: Our primary purpose is to design and execute independent synthetic biology research projects in order to compete in the annual iGEM competition.

name: Geophysical Sciences Undergraduate Union
description_preview: GeoUnion is a forum for undergraduate students to engage with members of the geoscience community and other related fields. We hold regular presentations given by graduate students, post docs, faculty, and other visitors focused at an undergraduate level
full_description: GeoUnion hosts meetings with presentations given by active members in the geosciences and other related fields. In addition to faculty and graduate students, we also provide an opportunity for undergraduates to practice presenting their own research. We have also brought in professionals working in geoscience-related fields to talk about opportunities other than academic careers. We host annual meetings with faculty and grad student panels to discuss the process of applying to graduate schools in the geophysical sciences and other post-college opportunities. We also organize field trips. Come by to enjoy cool science and free dinner!

name: German Club
description_preview: The University of Chicago German Club provides the entire UofC community with opportunities to engage with German language and culture, at any and all levels of proficiency and interest!
full_description: Please visit our website (https://uchicagogermanclub.wordpress.com/) to learn more about the German Club! Our Blueprint is not actively monitored.

name: Go Club
description_preview: Go is an ancient and intellectually rewarding board game. Our club hosts weekly Go activities, including teaching games, guest lectures, off-campus tournaments, and outdoors events. We foster competition and camaraderie, offering challenges and joy.
full_description: Whether you are a beginner or a high-Dan player, we warmly welcome you to join us. Out current members have diverse backgrounds, from nationally-ranked players to many who had never played the game before coming to our club. Whilst the game can involve complex strategies, its rules are rather simple and only take 5 minutes to learn.

name: Graduate Christian Fellowship
description_preview:
The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UChicago is a community of
grad students cultivating the love of Jesus in the academy, city, and world.
Whatever your background, join us as we learn about Jesus together.
full_description: Vision:Cultivating a Christ-centered community for the flourishing of UChicago Mission statement: We equip and encourage grad students to grow in Christ’s love, integrating faith and life. Whatever your background, join us as we learn about Jesus together. We're a part ofInterVarsity'sdivision ofGraduate and Faculty Ministries. Learn more on our website:gcf.uchicago.edu Contact us:Contact Form

full_description: A platform for students and affiliates to learn, train and compete in grappling martial arts (specifically Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu).

name: Groove Theory
description_preview: Groove Theory is a competitive collegiate dance crew dedicated to practicing street dance and spreading knowledge of hip hop culture. Come groove with us!
full_description: Groove Theory is a hip-hop dance crew dedicated to learning and performing the dance element of hip-hop culture. We study the foundations of various street styles including (but not limited to) breaking, waacking, popping, locking, house, and Chicago Footwork. We also help members apply these skills in cyphers, battles, and performances. Our main goal is not only to improve ourselves as dancers but also to spread awareness and share the history and culture of hip-hop in its true form. Groove Theory holds 2-hour practices twice a week and hosts 2-3 professionally led workshops a quarter.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Tuesday/6-8 pm/Logan Center | Friday/7-9 pm/Bartlett Arts Rehearsal Space

name: Guild of Change Ringers
description_preview: We ring the bells in the Reynolds club, and practice the ancient art of change ringing. New members are always welcome!
full_description: Change ringing is a form of campanology (bell ringing) which focuses on sounding bells in rhythmic sequences rather than playing tunes. By following a set of rules called methods a trained group of ringers may take the bells through a series of complicated sequences. The sequences are known as changes and the art is known as change ringing. Mitchell Tower in Reynolds Club has a set of bells hung for change ringing in 1908, making them the oldest set of University Change Ringing Bells in the United States.  We continue this proud tradition.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Saturdays 10:30am-1:00pm (in person); Wednesdays 5:00 pm-8:00 pm (in person)
additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website::
North American Guild of Change Ringers
http://www.nagcr.org/

name: Gymnastics Club
description_preview: A club dedicated to practicing artistic gymnastics and introducing students to gymnastics skills.
full_description: We are competitive and non-competitive, open to members ranging across all experience levels- including no experience. Practices are held 8-9:30 on Mondays during the Open Gym practice at CITY Gymnastics at XS Tennis, and 7:30-9:30 on Wednesdays and 2-4 on Saturdays during the Open Gym practice at Morgan Park Sports Center. (2024-25)

name: Harris Community Action
description_preview: Harris Community Action (HCA) is a student organization at the Harris School of Public Policy that connects students to local community-based organizations to lead data and policy projects primarily during the Winter Quarter.
full_description: Harris Community Action (HCA) is a student organization at UChicago’s Harris School of Public Policy. Formerly known as the Community Action Bureau (CAB), the organization was founded in 2014 with the broad goal of connecting about 50 policy students to local community-based organizations on the South and West sides of Chicago to contribute to the missions of these organizations.The main program of HCA is a 10-week winter quarter fellowship in January - March during which teams of 4-5 students are matched with a single organization to deliver a stand-alone project (working about 5 hrs/week/student). Our co-partnerships team of Board Members work over the summer to identify nonprofits with need, define a portfolio of about 10-12 projects across different policy areas for our fellows, and ensure that there is alignment with HCA fellow capabilities to ensure our fellows can provide these nonprofits with high-quality deliverables. Past projects have included: data identification, data analysis, recommendations for survey design and distribution, creation of intake forms, logic models, process improvement plans, etc. The HCA board welcomes conversations with organizations to discuss their current needs and the brainstorm how HCA fellows might be able to contribute

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: N/A (Board meets weekly but day/location/time change each quarter)

name: Health Professions Recruitment and Exposure Program
description_preview: HPREP members serve as mentors and friends to minority high school students. Area students travel to the University of Chicago campus to participate in a variety of lectures, discussions, and hands-on activities
full_description: The purpose of this organization is to expose underrepresented minority high school students to healthcare and provide medical students an opportunity to serve as mentors and friends to minority high school students who are underrepresented in medicine. The definition of minorities who are underrepresented in medicine as defined by the American Association of Medical Colleges is: “Underrepresented in medicine means those racial and ethnic populations that are underrepresented in the medical profession relative to their numbers in the general population.” These high school students come from high schools throughout the area to the University of Chicago campus several Saturdays during the winter quarter where they participate in a variety of lectures, discussions, workshops and hands-on activities with the goal of providing exposure to healthcare careers and skills to achieve their educational and career goals. Students also have an opportunity to connect with medical students and physicians.

name: Hellenic Student Association
description_preview: The Hellenic Student Association (HSA) brings students of both Hellenic and non-Hellenic backgrounds together in order to learn more about the culture, politics, and history of Greece. HSA will have social gatherings, discussions, and guest speakers.
full_description: The Hellenic Student Association (HSA) brings students of both Hellenic and non-Hellenic backgrounds together in order to learn more about the culture, politics, and history of Greece and Cyprus. HSA will have social gatherings, discussions, and guest lecture series in order to bring these interests together. We are centered on establishing a unified Greek/Hellenic community here on campus and, more importantly, hosting events for the whole University ranging from education about Greek culture/history/politics to entertainment including traditional Greek/Cypriot dance.

name: High Fidelity Music Collective
description_preview: Welcome to our club, where high fidelity music enthusiasts and record collectors unite to delve into the rich tapestry of music history. We're more than just a gathering of audiophiles; we're a community that explores music through book clubs, unraveling
full_description: Welcome to our club, where high fidelity music enthusiasts and record collectors unite to delve into the rich tapestry of music history. We're more than just a gathering of audiophiles; we're a community that explores music through book clubs, unraveling the stories behind the tunes that have shaped cultures and eras. From the smooth jazz of the 1920s to the psychedelic rock of the 1960s, we journey through different cultures and time points, immersing ourselves in the sounds that define each era. Our interests extend to the vibrant rhythms of Middle Eastern music, including the captivating sounds of Habibi Funk records, and the electrifying beats of African rock and roll. Join us as we celebrate the diversity and evolution of music, one record at a time.

name: Hindu Sangam
description_preview: The Hindu Student Sangam creates a space for Hindu students to learn about and grow in their religious/spiritual practices, organizing weekly prayer sessions and other events for yearly festivals.
full_description: The Hindu Student Sangam provides members of the University of Chicago community who are Hindu, or interested in learning more about Hinduism, an environment to practice, worship, and discuss topics pertaining to Hinduism. We have weekly meetings in Rockefeller Chapel's Uncommon Room (located in the Chapel's basement) for bhajans (devotional songs) and discussion.In addition, we collaborate with SASA and Rockefeller Chapel to hold campus-wide celebrations for some of the major religious holidays during the year, including Diwali and Holi. We also organize trips to mandirs (Hindu temples) in the Chicagoland area. These events are open to members from all sections of the University of Chicago community.

name: Hispanic and Luso-Brazilian Student Committee
description_preview: The Hispanic and Luso-Brazilian Student Committee (HBLSC) is a graduate student organization committed to the academic and intellectual development of the Spanish and Luso-Brazilian languages and literatures.
full_description: The purpose of the Hispanic and Luso-Brazilian Student Committee shall be to organize special events that facilitate encounters between graduate students and other scholars interested in Latin American, Caribbean, and Iberian studies from around the world. We aim for these encounters to be outside the usual academic environment of coursework and classroom lectures. Our interdisciplinary events, ranging from workshops to our annual graduate student conference, are planned by members to deepen their understanding of their areas of interest. The Hispanic and Luso-Brazilian Student Committee (HBLSC) aims to lead campus debates among students and faculty alike. Our vision is to create imaginative forums for discussion between the world's leading scholars and the students of the University of Chicago.

name: Hong Kong Student Association
description_preview: The Hong Kong Student Association aims to promote Hong Kong and its culture to all students at the University of Chicago through organizing cultural activities and study breaks.

name: HOPES 4 Foundations
description_preview: Through sustainable, direct consultations with Chicago principals & teachers, we strategically identify high-potential, overlooked students living in high-risk environments and support them for academic achievement across multiple years.
full_description: The purpose of this organization shall be to recruit and train UChicago students to help Chicago-based, K-6th grade students academically succeed by providing long-term support in science, math, and language. Through sustainable, direct consultations with Chicago principals & teachers, we strategically identify high-potential students and support them for academic achievement. We track progress academically each quarter based on their national testing percentiles. We believe that these students have high-achieving potential and deserve the opportunity to go to college. Our team of UChicago students provide academic coaching, on-campus experiential learning opportunities (to encourage them to pursue college), and internal support for the parent HOPES 4 Foundations organization (i.e., academic development and nonprofit research and design). We are currently seeking students interested in 1-1 coaching with K-8 students, as well as students interested in further developing our curriculum structures for math and language comprehension. Both positions will provide interactions with non-profit leadership personnel and opportunities for close collaboration and mentorship. We are also looking to develop back-end resources for organizing learning data in our organization. We encourage anyone with prior experience using Github.io and/or SQL to inquire. All interested applicants should email a brief cover letter and resume/CV to thomasl@uchicago.edu and rfritz@chicagohopesforkids.org.

name: Ice Hockey (Men's)
description_preview: UChicago Men's Ice Hockey Team
full_description: The University of Chicago Men's Ice Hockey Team is an on-campus club dedicated to providing students with the opportunity to stay on the ice and remain involved in the sport that we all love. The club is open to any student, regardless of experience or skill level, as long as you possess a passion for the game. The season begins in September and lasts roughly until Spring break. Because of this, it is recommended that equipment be brought to campus during your initial move-in so that you will have it for the start of the season. If you are interested in joining the team or have any questions, you can find the primary contact information on the home page.

name: Ice Hockey (Women's)
description_preview: We play various other university and recreational teams in the Chicagoland area and beyond; we are open to any interested university-affiliated women of all skill levels.
full_description: We are a women's recreational ice hockey team open to all interested university-affiliated women of all skill levels. We play in the Women's Central Hockey League against other teams in the Chicagoland area and are focused on player development.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Friday nights, 9:30 PM, Morgan Park Ice Arena

name: If/When/How: Lawyering for Reproductive Justice
description_preview: If/When/How: LRJ works to educate the community about reproductive justice issues and provides members with the tools necessary to advocate for reproductive justice and abortion access.
full_description: If/When/How: LRJ works to educate the community about reproductive justice and provides members with the tools necessary to advocate for reproductive justice.

name: Indigenous Students Association
description_preview: We strive to foster a welcoming and united community of Indigenous people and allies from all corners of the globe. Through cultural gatherings and community engagement, we aim to uplift the voices of Indigenous peoples and create a safe space.
full_description: We strive to foster a welcoming and united community of Indigenous people and allies from all corners of the globe. Through cultural gatherings and community engagement, we aim to uplift the voices of Indigenous peoples and create a safe space. We celebrate the breadth of Indigenous identity to connect, inspire, and empower our community. ISA is dedicated to serving as an educational resource and a platform for advancing the interests of Indigenous students within UChicago and the general Chicagoland area.

name: Indonesian Student Association at The University of Chicago
description_preview: We welcome everyone in University of Chicago community who has interest in Indonesia through our events and activities.

name: Institute of Politics
description_preview: The IOP aims to inspire and cultivate the next generation of political and public service leaders.
full_description: The idea for the Institute of Politics grew out of the lifelong experiences of its founding director, David Axelrod AB ’76, an accomplished political journalist, strategist and policy advisor, and his core belief that participation is essential to a vital, healthy democracy. Inspired by his own work with young people through various political campaigns and by the example of Harvard University’s Institute of Politics, Axelrod sought to establish a non-partisan program in Chicago that would provide students with opportunities to engage directly with the ideas, people and processes that shape politics today. Four core programs form the heart of the Institute: civic engagement opportunities that enable students to experience politics-in-action through political exploration trips, leadership training, service programs and voter engagement projects; visiting fellowships where distinguished political officials, policymakers, journalists, diplomats and others are in residence on campus during an academic quarter; political and public service internships that provide students with paid, substantive career development opportunities; and a continuous series of public events featuring leading political figures sharing their insights on key issues of the day.

name: International Leadership Council
description_preview: The International Leadership Council, founded in 2003, is the University of Chicago's premier student business organization, founded to provide students with a platform to share knowledge and ideas across finance, entrepreneurship, and technology.
full_description: The International Leadership Council is a University of Chicago student organization founded in 2003 by Karan Goel in order to connect business-oriented students and provide a platform for the sharing of knowledge and ideas. Over the past thirteen years, ILC has expanded to provide members with three updated, specialized divisions: Finance, Entrepreneurship, and Technology. Members innovate through entrepreneurial projects, lead discussions on market trends, and participate in trading contests and investment banking case competitions. Notable events include the our 100 Day Startup Challenge as well as Startup Fest, a day long celebration of startups near campus and in the Chicago area. Through these involvements, we connect with each other and the larger UChicago community. Financeaims to give its members a groundwork in financial theory and a setting to discuss market movements, practice industry research, and provide analysis and commentary. Entrepreneurship and Technologyprovides its members with hands-on experience in the business and logistics of creating and maintaining a start-up, as well as the opportunity and resources to collaborate in the creation and design of apps and web platforms. These divisions have created a supportive network on which to build and grow. With weekly meetings and a competitive membership, ILC remains one of the leading student organizations on campus.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Entrepreneurship & Technology:  Monday 7:00 PM @ Harper -- Finance: Sundays 1:00 PM @ Bartlett Lounge

name: International Student Organization
description_preview: International Student Organization aims to build a supportive and inclusive community of international students at UChicago by organizing social and professional events.
full_description: International Student Organization at UChicago is the first organization uniting students from 100+ countries through social, professional, mentorship, and cultural programming.

name: Jade Chinese Music Ensemble
description_preview: Jade Chinese Music Ensemble
full_description: The Jade Chinese Music Ensemble is a not-for-profit performing arts group serving the Chicago metropolitan area. Debuted in 2021 at the University of Chicago, the ensemble is dedicated to providing a performance space for musicians interested in the traditional and contemporary Chinese music and promoting cultural diversity in the music scene of Chicago. The ensemble connects performers and music lovers from across the university and communities beyond, allowing them to explore, collaborate, and create. The ensemble holds two concerts every year and performs in collaboration with the Chinese Fine Arts Society, the University of Chicago Department of Music, and in various cultural events in the Greater Chicago area.

name: Japanese Student Association
description_preview: JSA serves all students interested in Japan and Japanese culture. We hope to raise awareness of Japanese culture, language, and current issues among the student body as well as the local community through a variety of activities and events.
full_description: Our mission is to create an outlet for the Japanese community on campus and friends to openly discuss topics of Japanese lifestyle and current events, and to give university students unfamiliar with Japanese culture the opportunity to experience it. We hope to hold cultural events such as matsuri festivals and trips to Japanese establishments such as grocery stores and restaurants. In addition to cultural events, JSA connects its members with career opportunities in Japan through exclusive recruiting events.JSA is also expanding to be a line of support for incoming Japanese undergraduate students, Japanese high school students interested in attending university in the US, and short-term Japanese students of upper-level studies.

name: Jewish Law Student Association
description_preview: To sponsor activities and events that improve the social and educational life of Jewish students at the Law School and the University.
full_description: JLSA offers a wide range of programming to satisfy the diverse social, cultural, religious, and intellectual needs of Jewish students, and to introduce the Law School community to issues of importance to the world of Jewry. Our speakers include prominent federal judges, civil rights lawyers, public officials, journalists and academics. Our cultural/religious programming includes ever-popular Friday night dinners, bagel brunches, and holiday celebrations (Yom Kippur break-the-fast, Hanukkah party, Purim party, and Passover Seder).

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Every other Monday, 12:15, Room at the Law School's Discretion

description_preview: JGrads Chabad at UChicago
full_description: Jewish Chabad Organization for Grad Students at U-Chicago. Bringing Jewish Life to students who are away from home!

name: Joint Research Safety Initiative
description_preview: The Joint Research Safety Initiative (JRSI) is a research safety community run by students that aims to provide centralized and accessible safety and educational resources for students and faculty. Our safety and  efficiency is up to us, and only us.
full_description: Our goal is to foster a University-wide culture among administrators, professors, and researchers where safety is everyone's top priority. Additionally, we want researchers to take an active role in not just their own safety, but the safety of their colleagues.  To help develop this culture, the JRSI will focus on three areas. We will act as a liaison between U of C safety and lab safety contacts to help increase communication, provide a centralized accessible educational platform with resources for students and faculty, and educate lab safety contacts (LSC/Os)/officers (note that those two terms will likely be used interchangeably) and researchers on the principles and practices derived from Dow Chemical and other peer institutions.

description_preview: JOURNEES is a group of medical students interested in rural medicine and service learning. During academic breaks, students travel to rural underserved areas for clinical and community service experiences
full_description: JOURNEES' mission is to expose medical students to the healthcare needs of patients beyond the urban environment of Chicago, enabling them to learn about healthcare disparities in rural underserved communities while serving these communities. While we do engage in education and outreach events in the UChicago community, our main trip - to a rural community in the summer or winter - are the core of our work and mission.

name: Judo Club
description_preview: Dedicated to practicing judo ("gentle way", a Japanese martial art and Olympic sport) for competition, self-defense, good health, and camaraderie. No experience necessary!
full_description: Judo is a Japanese Martial Art and Olympic Sport invented by Dr. Jigoro Kano in Tokyo, Japan in 1882. Judo is a fantastic full body workout, competitive sport, recreational activity, and self defense system.The University of Chicago Judo Club is a tight-knit club committed to providing enjoyable, rewarding, and free instruction of judo to the UChicago community. Interested parties shouldjoin our listhost,our closed Facebook group "UChicago Judo" or our more active WhatsApp group chat and show up to practice in comfortable, athletic clothing ready for a rewarding workout. See you on the mat! WhatsApp Chat Link: https://chat.whatsapp.com/H7Qw81vSelwKj4NFf017Nx
