name: Real Estate Investment Group
description_preview: UChicago RIG offers students a platform to learn about real estate investing and explore real estate related careers in a collaborative community. We help students learn about real estate markets, investing, and how urbanization impacts communities.
full_description: NOW the Real Estate Investment GroupThe University of Chicago Real Estate Investment Group (“UChicago RIG”) offers undergraduate students a platform to learn about real estate investing and to explore real estate related careers in a collaborative community. We are the first and only investment club on campus focused primarily on real estate investing. The ultimate goal of RIG is to provide educational and professional development opportunities for UChicago students with an interest in pursuing a career in real estate and learning about real estate markets, investing, and how real estate investment and urbanization impact communities. In addition to our core focus of real estate markets and our primarily finance based curriculum, we will aim to grow awareness of the social issues associated with real estate and plan on facilitating discussions related to these topics by bringing in speakers and publishing reports related to the social and environmental side of real estate.

name: Remedy
description_preview: REMEDY is a student-run, philanthropic organization that aims to promote medical education, global health, and international service. We plan annual medical service trips abroad and donate funds to clinics that aid underserved populations.
full_description: REMEDY is a not-for-profit, nationwide medical student organization dedicated to addressing international health disparities through education and recycling of unused medical equipment. In 1991 Dr. William H. Rosenblatt, Professor of Anesthesiology at Yale University School of Medicine, founded REMEDY with the mission of collecting surgical supplies for use in medical mission trips to Latin America. The University of Chicago chapter of REMEDY has expanded Dr. Rosenblatt’s vision. In the past, REMEDY members have volunteered with the CerviCusco clinic in Cusco, Peru, an organization that is dedicated to providing needed healthcare and screening for women. Pritzker medical students from this chapter have also organized direct medical service trips to many locations around the world, including the Dominican Republic and Cuba. In the summer of 2023, the REMEDY team visited Centro de Salud Santa Clotilde, a health center along the Napo River in the Peruvian Amazon region of Loreto. Our team consisted of six first-year medical students and three family medicine physicians from the Chicagoland area. Through our partnership with the physicians and volunteers at Santa Clotilde, we were able to provide medical care to 412 patients in the area. Without the extra manpower, the doctors at Santa Clotilde would have been unable to travel to these distant communities and provide medical care. We hope to continue strengthening this newfound partnership with Santa Clotilde so that this can become an annual service trip.

name: Rhythm & Jews

name: Rhythmic Bodies in Motion
description_preview: Rhythmic Bodies in Motion (RBIM) is a dance RSO dedicated to providing a space for people of all abilities to dance. We take pride in featuring a diversity of dance styles and choreography. We run an annual showcase in the spring quarter.
full_description: As a reminder,RBIM is a dance RSO on campus that explores a variety of dance styles: contemporary, lyrical, jazz, bollywood, Chinese lyrical, etc. You name it, we have it! Our goal is to promote fun, accessibility, and diversity in dance! We have two different branches: RBIM General and RBIM Performance Company (PerfCo). RBIM General is open to people of all dance levels and the time-commitment is entirely dependent on one’s preference. No auditions needed! Everyone is welcome to join us for technique workshops and choreography sessions! RBIM Performance Company (PerfCo) is a smaller, audition-based group with a more intensive time-commitment for dancers with more experience. In addition to our Spring Showcase, PerfCo participates in several performances throughout the year. Stay in contact via: Instagram - @rbimperfco

Our past efforts earned us the 2022 Small College 7s National Championship. We have three practices a week during our competitive fall and spring seasons and we have team conditioning practices twice a week during the winter. We are a registered member of National Collegiate Rugby.

name: Ryerson Astronomical Society
description_preview: The quintessential purpose of RAS is to encourage all humanity to behold the celestial luminaries in hushed awe and to connect the community with UChicago's rich history of leading astronomy research.
full_description: The Ryerson Astronomical Society (RAS) is the University of Chicago's premier astronomy club dedicated to the belief that the stars belong to everyone. We bring the cosmos to life through our regular observation nights open to everyone, featuring our historic dome telescope on the roof of Ryerson Physical Laboratory. Astronomy, being the oldest of the sciences, is inseparable from its historical development. We work directly with the Astronomy and Astrophysics Department to connect students with the rich tradition of astronomy research at UChicago through research panels, Professor talks, and career advising. Weekly meetings are at 7 pm on Wednesdays at Ryerson 358, and observation nights are as frequent as weather allows. Some of our equipment includes an antique 6.25" refractor from the 1890s, a 8" reflector, and a 60" radio telescope.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Wednesdays at 7PM in Ryerson 358 and additional observation nights as weather allows

name: Scholars of Finance
description_preview: SOF is a values-oriented finance organization that aims to inspire character and integrity in the finance leaders of tomorrow.
full_description: Scholars of Finance (SOF) aimsto provide undergraduate students with leadership development, mentorship, and the active support of purpose-driven finance executives and investors. The mission of SOF is to inspire character and integrity in the finance leaders of tomorrow. The vision of SOF is a future where all finance leaders steward the world’s capital to serve the greater good. SOF also promotes diversity, equity and inclusion across the field of finance and in the communities in which we live and work. We implement our mission and support our six core values through regular meetings and our five programs. All new members undergo a series of group discussions known as the Leadership Development Program to learn about their values and create their own mission statement. We host industry professionals at speaker series events and connect them with our general members for mentorship. We also host Values Forums to reinforce SOF's principles and an annual symposium for networking opportunities.

name: Seers of the Divine Revelation
description_preview:
Spring 2024 New RSO

We are a group of seekers, dedicated to discovering and living by God's word in this modern age.
full_description: First, we promote leadership within every member. Each member is encouraged, rather than assigned, to lead and organize large or small-group events and services for which they feel a deep sense of mission. We provide thoughtful mentorship in spiritual principles throughout the whole planning process and the execution stage. Second, we view leadership as an act of serving, not a form of dominion. By serving others and learning from the Bible, our members will gain profound insights into the spiritual needs of today's youth and an understanding of the diversity of human beings. Third, we aim to develop deeper connections with each individual member. We will guide them to find their courage and encounter their challenges and further let them help more people in the same way. We will foster a culture where people learn to care for others genuinely and can find their life-long companions in pursuit of Christ.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website:: The Church of the Chicagoans: https://www.thechurchofthechicagoans.org/

full_description: Sensasia aims to provide a public platform and community for students to explore and celebrate the diversity of Asian heritages on campus through creative applications of the performing, material and culinary arts. Every year, we produce a cultural show featuring food and performing arts from across Asia and perform in other cultural shows on campus. Sensasia and its public events operate on a philosophy of equitable representation of the multiplicity of Asian populations throughout the student body, focusing particularly on providing performance opportunities for smaller groups that may otherwise not be able to showcase their heritages to a large audience.

Founded in 2012, it is a member of the SWS national organization with 25 chapters across the US. Through instructive seminars, mentoring initiatives, and meetings with successful investors such as Warren Buffett, SWS provides resources upon which women can build greater knowledge of financial markets. By giving young women direct investment experience while still in college, SWS aims to empower a new generation of women investors for the future.

full_description: The mission of SACNAS is to support inclusivity, professional advancement, and educational opportunity for STEM students from underrepresented groups. Our mission is to empower and provide the tools for all scientists to succeed in their respective fields, whether it be in academia or in industry. We provide personal and professional networking and development events. We provide opportunities for students to leverage their professional and personal networks, partake in the National SACNAS network, and to serve, support and lead our vibrant minority STEM student community on campus and in our community. We also strive to support inclusivity, holding events in which we can celebrate our culture and create a safe environment in which students can embrace their backgrounds. Together, we hope to prepare our members at the graduate and undergraduate level to lead with culture and identity to diversity the STEM fields.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website:: The Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science http://sacnas.org/

We do so by attending National and Regional conferences, hosting professional development workshops (resume reviews, graduate student applications, career panels, company recruitment, career fairs, etc.), and preparing students with soft skills (interviewing tips, public speaking). We are the only RSO that also advocates for APIDA scientists and engineers. We do so by partnering with APIDA organizations to advocate for our members inside and outside the classroom, celebrating cultural holidays, and building our community through shared experiences. We also believe in giving back to our community which we do by volunteering at local organizations and engaging with UChicago community members at science fairs and other festivals. All UChicago students (undergraduate and graduate) are welcome to join. Keep in touch with us throughDiscord,Instagram,email, and on theweb. description_preview: SAMSA is an organization that focuses on promoting the professional, political, and social goals of American pre-medical students, medical and dental students, residents, and fellows of South Asian heritage.
full_description: We strive to be leaders in healthcare and to provide a diverse forum for scientific, educational, cultural, charitable, and political interaction among our members. Our chapter provides a channel of networking, support, and open communication among our members nationally and between local chapters. Our group is focused on community service, educating the university community about issues of South Asian health, and interaction among medical professionals and medical and pre-medical students.

name: South Asian Students’ Association
description_preview: SASA aims to educate students about South Asian culture, history, and current events; entertain the University community with an array of cultural offerings; and engage members in a diverse, supportive peer network.
full_description: SASA programs throughout the year. Our major events are the Mehendi fundraiser and Diwali celebration (fall quarter), the annual culture show (spring quarter, with preparations throughout the winter), and Mela (spring quarter), but we also host a range of more intimate events to encourage thoughtful discussion and strengthen the SASA community. Our family system also pairs upperclassmen with a group of underclassmen and allows them to connect and form tight bonds over the course of the year. Note that our events are open to all members of the University community, regardless of heritage or familiarity with South Asian culture. Come to learn, talk about important issues, eat great food, and meet new people! SASA aims toeducatestudents about South Asian culture, history, and current events;entertainthe University community with an array of cultural offerings; andengagemembers in a diverse, supportive peer network.

name: South Side Free Music Program
description_preview: Teaching music to kids from underserved communities in Washington Park, Woodlawn, and Hyde Park.
full_description: The South Side Free Music Program was founded in 2010 in response to music program cuts in Chicago Public Schools and the symbolic message it sent about the value of arts education. Not all schools across the nation or even the city shared the same burden. SSFMP offers one-on-one music education for South Side students by pairing them with UChicago student teachers. We have teaching locations across Hyde Park, Woodlawn, and Washington Park, and hope to reach as many students as possible in order to help build positive community relationships and spread our love of music. Since its founding in 2010, the South Side Free Music Program has given hundreds of local students a one-on-one music education with University of Chicago student musicians. Our teachers have developed mentorship relationships with their students for 1, 2, or even 4 years. SSFMP has built a reputation as a strong community partner, working towards addressing problems of inequality and poverty for the betterment of Chicago and the South Side. If interested, fill out the signup form at our website https://ucssfmp.wixsite.com/ssfmp.

name: South Side Science Scholars
description_preview: S4 organizes afterschool science classes for elementary school students to help them consolidate the concepts they learned in classes. We hope to help students learn science through various hands-on activities.
full_description: Believing that human life may be enriched through the growth and dissemination of knowledge, this group is committed to developing, creating, and delivering a sustainable afterschool science curriculum to under-served Chicago grade schools, particularly those of the South Side. We aspire to positively impact children s scientific thinking, elements of health education, communication skills, and overall school preparedness.

name: Southside Scribblers

full_description: Southside Scribblers has been teaching creative writing to kids in Chicago since 1994. We work in conjunction with Ray Elementary School located right here in Hyde Park, teaching lessons once a week in-person. If you are interested in joining, please email us at uchicagoscribblers@gmail.com!

name: SPIE Student Chapter
description_preview: SPIE Student Chapters offer opportunities to collaborate with colleagues, perform outreach in the community, develop professional and leadership skills, form partnerships with industries, and can be a very rewarding student member experience.

name: Splash! Chicago
description_preview: Splash! Chicago is  dedicated to offering exciting learning opportunities to high school students in Chicago and teaching opportunities to University of Chicago students.
full_description: Splash! Chicago is a student organization at the University of Chicago that runs free after-school and weekend programs for high school students. Our goal is to introduce students from different walks of life to topics that aren’t approached in the traditional classroom — anything from pirate history and culture to tap dancing and religious cults — in a fun, collaborative setting. Our programs are open to all high school students; there’s no application and there’s no charge. We host two to three programs each year on the University of Chicago campus: Droplet runs annually on a Saturday in the fall or winter quarter and is attended by approximately forty high school students; Cascade runs Tuesday evenings during the winter or spring and is attended by thirty to fifty students. Finally, our largest event, Splash! runs annually on a Saturday in May. Students have the opportunity to explore several different subjects at Splash! and Droplet, while Cascade offers an opportunity to explore one or two subjects more in-depth. We have switched back to in-person events for the 2024-2025 school year. More information about our programs can be found on our website!https://splashchicago.learningu.org/

name: Sports Analytics Group at the University of Chicago
description_preview: We are a research-based organization dedicated to applying statistical, economic, and analytic tools to better understanding and predicting performance across a variety of sports markets. We research, publish, and present on different topics in sports.
full_description: We are a research-based organization dedicated to applying statistical, economic, and analytic tools to better understand sports and sports business. Through employer partnerships with various sports teams, we hope to pursue sports analytics projects and educational events for our members.

name: Student Global Health Alliance
description_preview: GHA @ UChicago is committed to fighting for health equity both domestically and abroad.  We apply global health to our partnerships, facilitating and supporting the operations of our partners in their quests to empower their target demographics.
full_description: Welcome to Global Health Alliance. Our mission is to fight forhealth equitythrough 1) partnerships with NGOs, 2) local initiatives, and 3) peer education.  We work with our partner organizations--DIN Malawi (Malawi) and Options for Youth (Chicago)--in a variety of capacities to help them support their bottom-line populations in the areas that help the most.We are a global and public health-focused RSOthat operates as a series of five teams all coordinated together, jointly working to serve our partners in asustainable, ethical way. GHA pairs implementation with research.  As a member of GHA, you will be educated on a variety of critical topics from the development and health spheres so that you may build a greater understanding of areas such as bioethics, charity complexes, health status, the social determinants of health, historical interventionist development failures, post-colonial dynamics, structures of power in the developing world, and much more. Then, armed with this knowledge, you will match with one of our five teams.  Equipped with an early understanding of how to approach partnership and development work in a sustainable, ethical manner, you'll then begin to work with our partners to serve their needs in any number of amazing, fulfilling, inspiring ways. GHA is an application-based student organization.  We have multiple application cycles every year, and we'd love to get you involved.  If you're interested in applying in our next active cycle, please contact global.health.alliance.uchicago@gmail.com.

name: Student Leadership Institute
description_preview: The Student Leadership Institute (SLI) offers students the opportunity to practice leadership skills in areas that will contribute to the success of their personal, academic, and professional goals.
full_description: The Student Leadership Institute (SLI) offers students the opportunity to practice leadership skills in areas that will contribute to the success of their personal, academic, and professional goals. SLI Participants will participate in a variety of activities, including bi-weekly meetings with alumni and leaders from the community and a group project of their choosing. Prior leadership roles in high school or college are not required – rather, a demonstrated interest in creating change on campus and developing resources for students. A desire to develop personal leadership and team building skills is required. Please visitour websitefor up to date information on our application timeline and ongoing projects.

name: Student National Medical Association - Graduate
description_preview: SNMA is committed to supporting current and future underrepresented minority medical students, addressing the needs of underserved communities, and increasing the number of clinically excellent, culturally competent and socially conscious physicians.
full_description: Organization Purpose:MissionThe Student National Medical Association (SNMA) is committed to supporting current and future underrepresented minority medical students, addressing the needs of underserved communities, and increasing the number of clinically excellent, culturally competent and socially conscious physicians.VisionThe SNMA commits to the empowerment of its members to take proactive steps to address minority health issues through advocacy and community service. As such, SNMA works to promote the professional development of its members, so that they may have the potential for being the underrepresented minority (URM) health leaders of tomorrow.SNMA commits to providing URM pre-health students withknowledge, skills and experiences that are both pre-requisite and concomitant to professional participation in the health care industry.SNMA commits to actively engaging in health advocacy to address inequities in medical education; racial/ethnic health disparities; and injustices in U.S. domestic and foreign health policy. SNMA will work to ensure equity in health care, serve as community health advocates, succeed as leaders in academic medicine, and direct health policy change.We encourage our membership to embody the ideals of the organization while maintaining leadership roles within SNMA; other professional organizations; and minority and underserved communities. We continue to advance the culturally competent URM medical student and future physician to achieve equal opportunity and health care for all.

name: Student National Medical Association-Minority Association of Pre-Med Students
description_preview: The Student National Medical Association is the nation’s oldest and largest organization focused on the needs and concerns of medical students of color. Membership includes nearly 6,000 medical students, pre-medical students, residents, and physicians.
full_description: The Student National Medical Association (SNMA) is committed to supporting current and future underrepresented minority medical students, addressing the needs of underserved communities, and increasing the number of clinically excellent, culturally competent, and socially conscious physicians.

name: Students for Disability Justice
description_preview: Students for Disability Justice is an RSO dedicated to bringing support groups and mentorship, disability activism, discussion, and community engagement to UChicago and the greater Chicago community.

name: Students for Justice in Palestine
description_preview: SJP is dedicated to raising awareness about the injustices concerning the occupation of the Palestinian people. We advocate for democratic and nonviolent principles to promote justice, human rights, equality, liberty, and self-determination.
full_description: Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) at the University of Chicago is dedicated to raising awareness about the injustices concerning the occupation of the Palestinian people. SJP at the University of Chicago advocates for the liberation of Palestine in all 1948 and 1967 occupied territory, between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea.As an advocacy group, SJP at the University of Chicago is committed to a core set of principles to which it expects its members to adhere. While the Palestinian people must ultimately be able to decide their future in Palestine, certain key principles grounded in international law, human rights law, and basic standards of justice are fundamental to a just resolution for the Israel-Palestine issue. These principles include the full decolonization of all illegally held Palestinian lands, the repatriation of Palestinian refugees in accordance with the Right of Return, an end to all discriminatory laws and systems targeting the indigenous Palestinian population, and a total end to the occupation of Palestine.Just as SJP at the University of Chicago condemns the discrimination underlying the policies and laws of Israel’s colonization of Palestinian land, SJP at the University of Chicago rejects and condemns all other forms of hatred, intolerance, or discrimination against any religious, racial, or ethnic group. This group is committed towards overcoming anti-Semitic sentiments towards both Arabs and Jews in every community.Rooting its strength in the diversity of its membership, SJP at the University of Chicago welcomes individuals of all backgrounds to join in solidarity with the struggle for freedom and justice in Palestine.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website::
National Students for Justice in Palestine
https://www.nationalsjp.org/

name: Students for the Exploration and Development of Space at UChicago
description_preview: SEDS empowers young people to participate and make an impact on space exploration through workshops, projects, and more!
full_description: Students for the Exploration and Development of Space (SEDS) is the university's premier space-related RSO. We aim to provide a place for all students interested in any and all aspects of space, aeronautics, astrophysics, engineering and more! As a club, we run two main projects: PULSE-A, UChicago's first-ever satellite and our NASA-sponsored mission that intends to demonstrate a novel form of laser communication, and High Power Rocketry, which has certified tens of students and will soon compete in the Spaceport America Cup - a national collegiate rocketry competition. We also offer career-building events such as lectures, certification training workshops, and research presentations. SEDS hosts a beautiful community of students in physics, enjoying movie nights, social outings, and our annual trip to the SpaceVision Conference. About the national organization: Students for the Exploration and Development of Space (SEDS) is a 501(c)3 non-profit that empowers young people to participate and make an impact on space exploration. SEDS helps students develop their technical and leadership skills by providing opportunities to manage and participate in national projects as well as to attend conferences, publish their work, and develop their professional network, in order to help students become more effective in their present and future careers in industry, academia, government, and education. SEDS was founded as a chapter-based organization in 1980 at MIT by Peter Diamandis, at Princeton University by Scott Scharfman, and at Yale University by Richard Sorkin. SEDS-USA was founded as a national group in 1982 by Peter Diamandis, Bob Richards, and Todd Hawley. The largest student-run space organization in the world, it consists of an international community of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students from a diverse range of educational backgrounds in chapters all over the world, including Canada, India, Israel, Mexico, Nepal, Nigeria, Philippines, Spain, United Kingdom, and the United States.

name: Supplies For Dreams, University of Chicago Chapter
description_preview: The mission of SFD is to enhance the education of low-income students at Chicago public schools. We aim to spark students' curiosity, open their eyes to the world of opportunities, and help them to build the mindset they will need to achieve their goals.
full_description: Supplies For Dreams is unique among organizations which engage with CPS students because we neither tutor students in any academic subject, nor provide direct assistance with homework or schoolwork. Our purpose is, rather, to help students gain the general mindset and skill set they will need to succeed at anything they want to pursue in life. We aim to grow students’ love of learning, broad worldview, confidence and agency, via a broad curriculum consisting of one-on-one mentoring and field trip programming, designed by the parent Supplies For Dreams nonprofit organization over the past several years (and constantly evolving). The fundamental motive behind SFD is that helping underprivileged kids with homework and schoolwork alone is not nearly sufficient to bridge the huge opportunity gap between them and those more privileged - one major measure of that gap being college enrollment, as 82% of Chicago Public School students, as of now, do not obtain a Bachelor's Degree. We have the ability to help bridge that gap in some significant ways. Our mentoring and field trip curricula are centered around the pillars of Agency, Self-Confidence, Broad Worldview, and Love of Learning - the four major characteristics we aim to improve in our students. Mentors work one-on-one, as well as in groups (groups of mentors working with groups of students) with 6th grade CPS students, once a week for 1.5 hours, at a time determined based on both CPS availability and our mentors' availability. The first part of our mentoring curriculum is focused on teaching CPS students about a wide spectrum of different careers (through a combination of teaching and active engagement of students in related activities which we have prepared), as well as what steps they would need to take in order to pursue those different careers. The next part of the mentoring curriculum involves guiding students through the conception and (ideally) actualization of their own ideas for a community service project, and then a new business/product. We walk students through the phases of brainstorming, how to begin a community service and business project, facing failures, measuring risks, budgeting, marketing, etc. This helps students grow confidence in their critical thinking skills and ability to achieve goals. Field Trip Hosts take 6th-8th grade students to places like the Museum of Science and Industry, the Field Museum, the Adler Planetarium, the Shedd Aquarium, the Chicago History Museum, and the Art Institute. The field trips, which are paid for by SFD, are designed to spark students' curiosity, broaden their worldview, and engage them in critical thinking - hosts prepare beforehand to talk to the students about what they are seeing in the museums, and to engage them in discussion about the history, science, art, etc. Each field trip host is expected to take part in at least 2 (of 4-5 total) field trips per quarter (several field trip hosts lead each field trip together). Field trips are always planned well ahead of time so that they take place at a time that works for both the UChicago hosts and the CPS student group. Further field trip programming includes a program called Kids To Campus, where students come to our campus to engage in activities led by multiple RSO’s (with the overall event being organized by us, in collaboration with those RSO’s), and through this gain insight into the opportunities available in college for exploration of one’s interests, personal growth, and career advancement.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Monthly Virtual Meetings (date/time determined by when2meet polls)

name: Sustainable Investing Group
description_preview: We're spreading awareness about the power of social entrepreneurship and impact investing. Our members go through a 15-week educational curriculum followed by academic year internships at local impact investing funds, social enterprises, and nonprofits.
full_description: With a robust 15-week training program and a hands-on approach to real-world problems, the UChicago SustainableInvestingGroup invites members to develop a deep understanding of the principles inherent to impact investing. We seek to illuminate an area of the financial sector that is growing rapidly but under-represented in undergraduate finance education. TheUChicago Socially ResponsibleInvestingGroup provides its members with a unique opportunity to learn about real-world applications of impact investing. We provide guest speakers from academia and the public/private sector and analyze impact investing case studies through our curriculum in order to provide a concrete context for the field. Through our partnerships with impact investing funds in Chicago, impact-oriented nonprofits, and social enterprises, our analysts receive internships that provide hands-on experience, working closely with industry professionals. Through developing both a professional network and professional skills, our members are equipped to break into their respective fields of finance, consulting, social impact, etc.

name: Table Tennis Club
description_preview: This organization is for people in the University of Chicago community who are interested in playing table tennis as a fun, recreational activity.
full_description: This organization is for people in the University of Chicago community who are interested in playing table tennis as a fun, recreational activity. Make sure to like ourFacebook page, join ourFacebook group, and sign up for ourmailing listfor the most up-to-date information!

name: TableTop Tuesdays
description_preview: Providing tabletop gaming to the UChicago community.
full_description: We're a community dedicated to playing tabletop roleplaying games (TTRPGs) and other board games. At our once-weekly meetings on Tuesdays at 7:00 in Crerar's Weston Game Lab, we create a safe, respectful, and inclusive environment in order to give both beginner and veteran TTRPG players the opportunity to tell collaborative stories through gaming. We also curate and share member-created, tabletop-oriented content for the larger UChicago community. Join Our Discord Here!

name: Tae Kwon Do Club
description_preview: The University of Chicago Tae Kwon Do Club
full_description: Taekwondo can be roughly translated as "The Way of the Hand and Foot" and is a traditional Korean martial art. Officially introduced as an Olympic Sport in 2000 and thought to be the world's most popular martial art, Taekwondo has a history that stretches back to ancient Korea. As the name suggests, Taekwondo is more than a sport or fighting style, it is a way of life. The ultimate goal of Taekwondo is self-improvement through disciplining the mind and conditioning the body. The University of Chicago Taekwondo Club is led and taught by volunteer members of the university community. As our instructors come from a variety of training backgrounds there is a diversity of style not present in many traditional schools. This results in a training environment that is collaborative rather than dogmatic. For anyone interested in learning a martial art or improving their physical fitness in a friendly environment, the Taekwondo Club is an excellent choice. We welcome students of all skill levels and types of martial arts experience. Please contact an instructor if you have questions. If you want to know if Taekwondo is for you, the best way to find out is to try a class.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Autumn Meetings: M/W 7-8:30 PM, Th 8:45-10:30 PM and Sat 10 AM-12 PM. Join our email list for info on demo and sparring practice!

description_preview: Taiwanese American Student Association (TASA) is an organization that strives to explore Taiwanese culture as well as engage and educate the greater University community about Taiwan and Taiwanese culture.
full_description: Taiwanese American Student Association (TASA) is an organization that strives to explore Taiwanese culture as well as engage and educate the greater University community about Taiwan and Taiwanese culture.

name: Taiwanese Student Association
description_preview: Taiwanese Student Association (TSA) at the University of Chicago is a voluntary society devoted to discussions of cultural, social, and political issues in Taiwan, and to promoting Taiwanese culture to the US campus.
full_description: Taiwanese Student Association (TSA) at the University of Chicago is a voluntary society devoted to discussions of cultural, social, and political issues in Taiwan, and to promoting Taiwanese culture to the US campus. TSA also provides Taiwanese students services of orientation, consultation, and information to get around on campus and in Chicago. As a member of the UC Registered Student Organizations (RSO), TSA welcomes anyone who shares common interests with us. A registered UC student status is required to be an official member of TSA. However, everyone is welcome to join our common activities.

name: TAMID Group
description_preview: TAMID is dedicated to training the next generation of motivated, business-minded students through consulting and finance education and experiential learning. Members provide management consulting services to Israeli startups and evaluate investments.
full_description: TAMID at the University of Chicago is dedicated to training the next generation of motivated, business-minded students through consulting and finance education and experiential learning. New members complete a quarter-long comprehensive education program in their respective divisions. The Fund manages a $60,000+ equity portfolio, led by students who analyze and pitch stocks to the national board. The Consulting division provides pro-bono management consulting services to Israeli startups. Projects include product market analysis, business growth planning, and corporate strategy deliverables. Members can apply to participate in a fellowship program that matches students with internship opportunities in Tel-Aviv. TAMID Group is a national organization with more than 60 recognized chapters across the United States. Though we run completely independently, the TAMID organization gives its members the opportunity to network with and learn from other students and TAMID alumni and participate in events such as regional and national conferences, speaker series and professional development training. To learn more and join, visit our websitehere!

name: Tap That!
description_preview: Tap That is an organization of dancers passionate about making funky rhythms with their feet! Join us for weekly beginner and/or advanced classes.
full_description: Tap That is an organization of dancers passionate about making funky rhythms with their feet! As UChicago's best (and only) tap dancing group, we are committed to spreading the love of tap dance and creating a dynamic tap community on campus. No experience is needed to join! Stop by our beginner, intermediate, or advanced classes for opportunities to perform at showcases, community events, and Where Fun Comes to Dance. If you're not sure which classes are the best fit for you, feel free to reach out to Sarah Thau (sarahthau@uchicago.edu). Follow us on Instagram @tapthatuchicago and join our listhost to stay up-to-date on all the "tappenings" on campus! Check out some of our advanced group's past performances: 2023 Set 2022 Set 2019 Set 2018 Set

full_description: Tech Savvy Friends is a service RSO dedicated to bringing digital literacy to senior citizens in the Kenwood/Hyde Park neighborhoods through intergenerational friendship.

name: Tennis Club
description_preview: The Tennis Club is a resource for players of all levels, from beginners to highly experienced, to enjoy the sport of tennis.  We offer opportunities for both recreational tennis and intercollegiate competitive match play.
full_description: Our primary goal is simply to provide a resource for the tennis community of the University of Chicago and Hyde Park. Our members range from highly experienced and competitive players to those picking up a racquet for the first time. We hold regular practices year-round, the primary location being at Stagg Field on 56th and Cottage Grove. When the weather gets cold, we rent indoor courts at XS Tennis Club. For recreational players, we have no member fees and no minimum time commitment. We also provide equipment and lessons, if needed. For those with a more competitive spirit, we compete in the USTA Midwest Tennis On Campus League against other collegiate teams. This is highlighted by spring trips to the regional and national championship tournaments. We hold tryouts in the fall and have a mandatory weekly practice for our competitive team.

name: Thai Student Association
description_preview: The purpose of the Thai Students' Association shall be to promote international understanding of the Thai culture and friendship with Thai people through cultural and social activities among members of the university community.
full_description: ThaiSA aims to promote Thai culture to members of the University of Chicago and its surrounding communities through various activities including its signature Thai Night event.

name: The Black Graduate Coalition
description_preview: The Black Grad Coalition (BGC) is a campus organization which serves as a student union for all Black graduate and professional students at UChicago, with an intentional focus on community building, campus activism, and civic engagement.
full_description: The Black Grad Coalition is an organization at UChicago, dedicated to building community among Black graduate and professional students, community members, and alumni through activism, service, and civic engagement. It is also an organization which aims to center the needs of Black graduate students during their time on campus. Too often, graduate students can feel as though their needs are not prioritized by the administration and, given the decentralized nature of the UChicago system, the opportunities to regularly connect with students across divisions are few. From our vantage point, this experience is only exacerbated for Black graduate students here. BGC hopes to actively disrupt that reality and bring Black grads together. We celebrate Black excellence, Black community, and Black culture. We seek to amplify Black voices, speak out against racial injustice, and claim space where we have historically been kept at the margins--continually striving to dismantle any and all systems of white supremacy.

name: The Chicago Skeptics Society
description_preview: As a community, we seek to examine religion and its accompanying philosophies in a critical light. Our meetings are filled with thought provoking questions, enriching discussions, and LOTS of snacks! All religious and areligious backgrounds are welcome.

full_description: The Classics Society is an academic and social club dedicated bringing together Classics enthusiasts at UChicago. We're excited to welcome members from all academic backgrounds and levels of interest, and we hope to see you at our Greek/Latin reading group, departmental social events,Animus Classics Journalworkshops, and the occasional toga party.

full_description: Our goal is to provide students with a platform for artistic exploration in photography and to connect students who have this passion. We intend to help members by teaching students a variety of photographic techniques through workshops, expanding student access to photographic and development equipment, and providing a community and space in which students can share their photographic work.

name: The Ransom Notes
description_preview: The Ransom Notes is an all-gender a cappella group, that can be found performing on campus, at local venues in Hyde Park, and all around the city of Chicago. We annually compete in the ICCA competition, and bi-annually visit colleges around the US.
full_description: The Ransom Notes is an all-gender a cappella group that can be found performing on campus, at local venues in Hyde Park, and all around the city of Chicago. We annually compete in the ICCA competition, and bi-annually visit colleges and cities around the country, during our Spring Tour. The Notes have been a vocal presence at UChicago for the past 26 years, and most recently, we released our album entitled "RN FM", available on Spotify, along with music videos from our 2022 ICCA set, available on YouTube. Look forward for more music releases to come! We're a fun-loving group of musicians that loves each other as much as we love to sing. Our members most enjoy performing in informal arch sings, teaching music workshops to high school students around the South Side during our annual Chicago-focused Winter Tour, and singing carols at invited Holiday markets.

description_preview: Southside Free Clinic
full_description: Southside Free Clinic

name: The Student Research Society
description_preview: Student Research Society’s (SRS) mission is to create and foster a community of passionate undergraduate researchers  who can connect about their research experiences at UChicago and provide advice for finding undergraduate research opportunities.
full_description: Student Research Society’s (SRS) mission is to create and foster a community of passionate undergraduate researchers from many different fields and backgrounds who can connect about their research experiences at UChicago and provide advice for finding undergraduate research opportunities. Finding an undergraduate research position should not be an opaque, confusing, or difficult process—we want to supply students with the resources they need to find a position that works for them and provide them with a community to support them.

name: The Triple Helix
description_preview: The Triple Helix is a student-led undergraduate organization dedicated to exploring the relationship between science and society. We realize this mission through our two print journals, e-publication, and events.
full_description: The Triple Helix (TTH) is an undergraduate organization that addresses pressing science-related issues in today’s society from novel, interdisciplinary perspectives.We publish two print journals—Science in Society Review and Scientia—biannually, and an e-publication, The Spectrum, quarterly.Writers tackle interdisciplinary topics in the natural, physical, and social sciences and have a strong support system of fellow undergraduate editors. We also host multiple events each quarter to complement the themes explored in our journals. Overall, members of The Triple Helixhave the opportunity to write and edit articles, publish their own research, and host events. Through this, our members build valuable skills in leadership, communication, and collaboration and deeply explore their interests in science. Members are also able to network with eminent professors and professionals through our events and writing opportunities. To see examples of past journals and events, check out ourissu!

name: The Underground Collective
description_preview: A safe-space performance collective comprised of writers and performers who put on quarterly showcases featuring music, poetry, dance, comedy, and multi-art collaborations.
full_description: The Underground Collective is a unique University of Chicago safe-space performance collective composed of student performers who put on themed quarterly showcases of entirely original work, including poetry, music, dance, comedy, theater, and multi-art collaborations. We are dedicated to creating a safe space for all participants, both audience members and performers.

name: The University of Chicago Glee Club
description_preview: CMAC is a traditional low-voices glee club which provides a platform for the musical and personal development of its members.
full_description: CMAC'srepertoire is diverse, spanning genres from Renaissance polyphony to 1950s doo-wop and pop, English and Irish drinking songs, University of Chicago school songs, and much more. Our members share a passion for music and commitment to excellence. We are committed to promoting both the musical and personal development of our members, believing that a CMAC member should be a singer, but also a scholar and well-rounded individual.

full_description: The purpose of the University of Chicago Golf Club is to provide a fun environment for people to learn and play golf, both recreationally and competitively.

name: The University of Chicago Mexican Association
description_preview: The University of Chicago Mexican Association is the official student organization for that gathers Mexicans studying at The University of Chicago and students interested in Mexican current affairs and culture
full_description: University of Chicago Mexican Association is the official student organization for Mexicans studying at The University of Chicago. The organization is seeking integration of the Mexican student community across the University and promoting awareness and knowledge of Mexico. Our goals are to: I) Facilitate a proactive integration of the Mexican Community at UChicago across schools and fields of study through academic, cultural, and social activities II) Promote information and discussion in the University on various topics whose common subject is its relevance for Mexican society III) Uphold and promote individual and collective interests from our community in the academic and professional spheres

name: The University of Chicago Tea Club
description_preview: Our mission is to bring people together through a simple cup of tea. We also aim to educate people on the history, culture, and practice of tea and to show people how wonderful a good cup of tea can really be!

name: The Visuals Series

full_description: Provides graduate students in the chemistry department with the opportunity to practice the presenting their scientific research. Also gives the audience (mostly students in chemistry) a chance to find out what kind of research is going on within the department, as well as engage the speaker with any questions they may have on their experience or research.

full_description: This organization partners with local Chicago schools and community centers to get elementary school-aged students from low-income communities interested in STEM and combat the socioeconomic divides in those fields. Through our custom approach, each lesson has each student take on the roles of a student, collaborator, and instructor in order to build their confidence and interest in STEM fields. full_description: Turkish Students Association is an RSO with the mission of connecting undergraduate students from Turkey and all those who are interested about Turkey and its culture.

name: Turning Point USA at UChicago
description_preview: We are the Turning Point USA Chapter at the University of Chicago! We work to get students excited about our country's achievements, our US Constitution, and the value of free speech.
full_description: We are the Turning Point USA Chapter at the University of Chicago! We work to get students excited about our country's achievements, our US Constitution, and the value of free speech. If you are a student or faculty member at the University of Chicago and want to get more info, don't hesitate to contact us at tpusaatuchicago@gmail.com. Other inquiries, such as media requests, can be sent to the same email address.

name: UC Dancers
description_preview: UC Dancers is the University of Chicago's oldest dance group, specializing in contemporary, lyrical, and jazz dance styles.
full_description: We aim to foster an encouraging, supportive, and creative environment for dancers of all levels to express themselves through contemporary, lyrical, and jazz dance. We achieve this goal through open company auditions, by encouraging student improvisation, and by featuring student choreography and performances in our annual showcase. For more information, check out ourwebsiteand follow us onFacebookandInstagram!

name: UC Psych
description_preview: UC Psych is a student organization that aims to promote the study and science of Psychology. Anyone interested in psychology is welcome, regardless of major!
full_description: UC Psych is the undergraduate psychology club at the University of Chicago. We welcome all students who are interested in the field of psychology--majors and non-majors alike. The University of Chicago UC Psych hosts multiple events throughout the school year that aim to provide students with access to lab opportunities, perspectives on applying to graduate school, feedback from professional psychologists, and input about summer opportunities for undergraduates. Our club organizes psychology-related academic and social events, such as faculty and grad student talks, movie nights, class registration workshops, and study breaks.

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Tuesday, 5 PM, Regenstein Library (room announced weekly via listhost)

name: UChicago Aag
description_preview: Formed in 2014, UChicago Aag is the University of Chicago's premier South Asian Fusion Acappella group.
full_description: As UChicago's premier South-Asian a cappella group, UChicago Aag aims to showcase the diversity of South Asian music in a way that bridges cultures and communities across a broad spectrum. Despite being a relatively new group, we have already acquired an extensive repertoire of musical arrangements, and have established a unique space on campus, attracting fans and performers from all backgrounds. We love ladoos and making fusion music!

name: UChicago ACM
description_preview: UChicago ACM strives to foster communication and collaboration within the University's computer science community, supporting members' professional growth through opportunities for learning, career development, and networking.
full_description: UChicago ACM is the University of Chicago’s student chapter of the world’s largest educational and scientific computing society, the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM). We are advised by the Ian T. Foster. As a student chapter, our mission is to promote the ACM’s goal of “advancing computing as a science and a profession” amongst the University of Chicago’s students (undergraduate or graduate). To this end, we currently have two committees in machine learning and software engineering. These committees meet weekly to give students hands-on experience outside of the classroom. UChicago ACM also holds general meetings that give students the opportunity to connect and learn from professionals in various industries of computer science.

name: UChicago Air Force ROTC
description_preview: The purpose of this organization shall be to fulfill the AFROTC mission at the University of Chicago, and develop leaders of character for tomorrow's Air Force and Space Force.
full_description: The purpose of this organization shall be to develop Air andSpace Forceleaders of character whom we expect to fight and win our Nation's wars.

name: UChicago Alt Protein Project
description_preview: Spring 2024 New RSO
full_description: We are the UChicago Alt Protein Project, a group of students passionate about alternative proteins and the future of food. Together, we share the dream of a global food system that’s better for the planet, people, and animals. Our main priority is to create an inclusive community that generates excitement and awareness for alternative proteins among students and faculty. This looks like speaker events, food tastings, networking, and reading groups. Beyond this, we aim to educate students about alternative proteins and to help them build their careers. This means creating alternative protein courses at UChicago in thePritzker School of Molecular Engineering, working with our Career Advancement Office, and helping students find relevant and exciting research projects.

name: UChicago Behavioral Economics Association
description_preview: UChicago's first Undergraduate Behavioral Economics Club. The club aims to attract Behavioral Economics enthusiasts lwithin the UChicago community and develop relationships with employers to identify opportunities to pursue the field.
full_description: The University of Chicago Behavioral Economics Association (UCBEA) was founded in April 2020 by a group of eight motivated students and has since grown to include over 50 dedicated members. Our mission is to explore the intricacies of behavioral economics and its applications, fostering both academic and professional development within the UChicago community. UCBEA has established a valuable partnership with UChicago’s Career Advancement Department, allowing us to organize an array of webinars featuring esteemed professors from The College and Booth School of Business. We offer weekly meetings, information sessions with employers, and seminars led by leaders in the field, providing members with opportunities to expand their knowledge and networks. Our activities are organized into three primary pillars: **1. Academic Engagement:** Members can engage with our two student-designed journals, “Behave,” which delve into behavioral science concepts and their real-world applications. We also host speaker events featuring acclaimed professors, allowing members to learn from their research and expertise. **2. Professional Development:** UCBEA empowers aspiring entrepreneurs by providing tailored strategies to optimize operations, enhance customer acquisition, and develop effective marketing plans. Through hands-on case competitions and client-facing BeSci consulting projects, members gain practical experience and valuable insights. **3. Social Connections:** We prioritize community building within UCBEA through various social activities. Members can join mentee pods, participate in point picnics, and enjoy events like visits to the Mindworks lab, Secret Santa, festive potlucks, and Chinatown dinners, fostering friendships and collaboration among peers. Join us in our commitment to exploring behavioral economics through a blend of academic rigor, professional development, and community engagement. UCBEA welcomes all students interested in understanding and applying the principles of behavioral economics to real-world challenges.

name: UChicago Bhangra
description_preview: UChicago's one and only competitive Bhangra dance team.
full_description: Bhangra refers to a form of music and dance that originated in the Punjab region of India and Pakistan. It was traditionally performed at harvest festival celebrations and the lyrics often refer to the history and hardships of the Punjab region. Through the Punjabi diaspora, however, Bhangra has grown in popularity all over the world, and it has also been influenced by Western styles. Today there is a flourishing competitive circuit in the United States and Canada in which collegiate and independent teams compete each year. Physically, Bhangra is a very energetic dance form and includes the use of many props, including saaps (wooden musical instruments), khunde (staffs), and dhols (large drums).The UChicago Bhangra team (UCB) strives to promote Bhangra as a dance and art form to the university community and the greater Chicagoland area. Bhangra is fun to watch and even more fun to dance, so we invite you to dance along and cheer us on whenever you see us perform!

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Tuesdays & Thursday, 9-11 PM Ida Noyes Dance Room; Sunday 7-9pm Ida Noyes Dance Room

name: UChicago Biotechnology Association
description_preview: The mission of the UChicago Biotechnology Association (UCBA) is to provide resources and opportunities for career education and skill development to UChicago students and post-doctoral scholars.
full_description: The UCBA has three primary goals:

name: UChicago Ceramics

full_description: follow @uchicagoceramicsclub on Instagram for info about sessions or email us if you don’t have Instagram. clay and glazes provided!

name: UChicago Chinese Opera Society
description_preview: The only Chinese Opera organization on campus! We focus on Kunqu and Peking Opera but all is welcome :)
full_description: The UChicago Chinese Opera Society aspires to increase the presence of the various Chinese theatrical traditions, to build a platform for performers of these traditions, to provide access for those new to these traditions to learn and engage, and to foster musical and cultural diversity in the University of Chicago and its local communities.

name: UChicago Credit Group
description_preview: Spring 2024 New RSO
full_description: The mission of UChicago Credit Group (UCG) is three fold - we hope to build an organization that focuses on building students’ interests in the niche space of Credit through an educational curriculum, provide networking and recruiting opportunities in this area, and provide real world credit modeling and project management experience.

name: UChicago Data Science Society
description_preview: UChicago Data Science Society
full_description: UChicago Data Science Society aims to build a community for data science students across the university, in response to the increasing demand for and interest in data science skills, majors, and professions. The organization provides an alternative space that is more casual than an academic context for people to learn and discuss data science as well as connect with each other. Collaborating with the data science department, the organization will serve as a bridge and connect students with faculties and potential academic/professional opportunities. In addition to fostering community and facilitating connections, the organization offers hands-on learning experiences through selective project opportunities. Members can apply to participate in real-world data science projects, allowing them to gain practical experience, enhance their skills, and build their portfolios. These projects provide a valuable complement to academic coursework, enabling members to apply their knowledge in tangible ways and prepare for future careers in the field. Please reach out if you have any questions!

name: UChicago Effective Altruism
description_preview: UChicago Effective Altruism aims to provide a space for effective altruists and intends to promote the ideas of effective altruism—the view that we should apply evidence to find the most high-impact ways to improve the world.
full_description: Hi! We're interested in learning how to do good for the world in the most effective way possible. We believe that it is both possible and necessary to harness the world's altruistic energy in a way that uses evidence and philosophy to find the most high-impact ways to improve the world. This includes thinking carefully about global poverty and development, the subjugation of animals in factory farms and animal welfare, the development of AI safety alongside general AI, and the welfare of future peoples, among so many other cause areas. If you're passionate about making the world a better place, not sure how you can substantively make the world a better place, or just interested in talking more, we'd love to see you shoot an email to ea.uchicago@gmail.com. We can't wait to hear from you! More ways to stay updated Add our calendar Joinour Slack,listhostand/orfollowour Facebook page to stay updated

additional_info.Regular Meetings (Day/Time/Location):: Thursday 7-8, Bartlett Lounge (just turn right at the bottom of the exit stairs!)

name: UChicago Energy & Climate Club

full_description: The Energy & Climate Club is a community forundergraduate students interested in the energy and climate sectors. We seek to foster engagement through educational programming and pre-professional career opportunities via hands-on projects, competitions, and networking.

full_description: The University of Chicago Geographic Studies Club (UCGEO) is a general-interest student-led group for undergraduate students to explore the world from the classroom by learning geography and geographic information science through a rich program of engaging activities. Beyond the classroom, our mission extends to the Greater Chicago Area, coordinating with foreign consulates, geographic networks, and other universities to host student visits to foreign missions, museums, libraries, and other geography-related events. full_description: UChicago＋ ("UChicago Plus" or "Plus") is a social RSO focused on connecting LGBT+ undergraduate and graduate students across campus. Our group is community-run and any member can propose and organize an event. Regular events include coffee meet-ups, weekly board game nights, and grad student pub night. We encourage all LGBT+ students, including those questioning their gender or sexuality, to join us. Since we were formed during the pandemic, we primarily communicate through our Discord server. This also allows anonymity for students currently exploring their identities or who are uncomfortable coming out. If you're interested in meeting us, join ourDiscord server! Keywords: LGBT, LGBTQ, gay, lesbian, homosexual, bisexual, asexual, non-binary / nonbinary, transgender, LGBTQIA+, gender, sexuality, identity, queer, intersex

description_preview: This organization seeks to serve as a support network for Quest Scholars, Odyssey Scholars and all First-generation, Low-income students at UChicago. We provide mentoring, networking, and leadership opportunities for our members.
full_description: The Quest Chapter ultimately aims to increase socioeconomic diversity of our nation’s top schools and societal leaders. The Quest Chapter at UChicago channels this mission by providing a supportive social network for not just QuestBridge scholarship recipients, but for all low-income and first generation students as well as those that wish to support them. We aim to build a supportive and welcoming community for these students by furthering their access to academic, leadership, and social service opportunities, thereby narrowing the gap between talented low-income college students and their peers. The chapter is a vibrant community of students with a passion for socioeconomic diversity, intellectual rigor, and giving back to the community.

full_description: Join our Discord:https://discord.gg/FmY5fZmFollow us on Twitch:https://twitch.tv/uchismash UChicago Smash hosts weekly tournaments in the MADD Center, and a large inter-collegiate tournament known as ICCS (Inter-Collegiate Chicago Smash) in conjunction with the Smash scenes at other universities. The UChicago TO team currently consists of five volunteers: Kurt "KurtSwitch" Fischer (4th Year), Braden "Crumple" Hajer (4th Year), Ron "Daemon" Gneezy (4th year), Colin "Potso" Yao (4th), and Anthony "OneKyaaa" Yoon (2nd). full_description: UChicago Transit Enthusiasts and Explorersfosters a community for students interested in transit/transportation within the Chicagoland area and beyond. We promote awareness in the University community about the benefits and usefulness of public transportation through excursion events, speaker series, and other activities, as well as provide the opportunity to advocate on the local and state levels for improved transit access for all Chicagoans. ‎ㅤㅤ How to getinvolved Check out ourNew Member Guideto learn about joining UCTEE and join ourDiscordto engage with our growing community of undergraduates and graduate students, and/or join our Listhost by requesting to join us on Blueprint. ‎ㅤㅤ All events are posted on our Discord and sent out to our Blueprint list host. All public events are posted to our Blueprint page. ㅤㅤ‎ What kind of events do you hold? Speaker events, group excursions to city landmarks like the Pullman Historical Park, plane & train spotting, study breaks, group travel to transit advocacy events, survey research projects, and more...

name: UChicago Triathlon Club
description_preview: The triathlon community encourages multi-sport engagement at UofC, providing both a competitive and recreational support system. We are an active community with a wide range of experience levels. We support members competing locally and nationally.
full_description: Our triathlon team is both a competitive and recreational club on campus that focuses on expanding a multi-sport community of people who love training together. Furthermore, our members range across all levels of experience, in each of the three triathlon segments (swim, bike, run). Our coach, Linda Taillon, is a 3-time Ironman World Championship qualifier. full_description: The Vietnamese Student Association seeks to facilitate Vietnamese cultural exploration and engagement for the UChicago community and beyond. Our events include traditional holiday celebrations, guest speaker events and arts showcase (poetry reading, movie screenings, etc.) with Vietnamese food. VSA starts out asa community of over 30+ Vietnamese students across all years and divisions of the University and welcomes anyone who is interested in Vietnamese culture. Although one has to be a registered UChicago student to hold membership within VSA, everyone is invited to our common events.

name: Undergraduate Investment Banking Group
description_preview: UIBG provides students with educational seminars specific to investment banking, and hosts case competitions, guest speakers, and networking opportunities with top investment banks and alumni in order to prepare students for the recruitment process.
full_description: The Undergraduate Investment Banking Group (UIBG) is a registered student organization (RSO) on the campus of the University of Chicago. The group dedicates itself to the promotion and education of its group members toward a career in investment banking and finance. Its main events include weekly meetings and seminars where various investment banking topics and technicals are taught, annual case competitions, networking events, and guest speakers where members have an opportunity to meet with industry professionals and investment bankers, along with other opportunities for members to get to know the industry better. Our past group alumni include former/current investment bankers from Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan, Lazard, Morgan Stanley, Evercore, Qatalyst, Credit Suisse, Centerview, and other notable investment banks. To learn more about the RSO and leadership, visit our official website at http://www.uibguchicago.com/ Or contact us directly at uibguchicago@gmail.com.

full_description: The Philosophy Club provides a forum for the exploration of philosophical ideas outside of the classroom. We especially aim to showcase undergraduate work through student presentations of their own papers. We welcome anyone to join the discussion.

name: Undergraduate Student Government
description_preview: Undergraduate Student Government's (USG) mission is represent the University of Chicago undergraduate population, address student concerns, and create positive changes in the broader collegiate, University, and Chicago communities.

name: United Against Inequities in Disease
description_preview: UAID is dedicated to combating health inequities in neighboring communities through partnerships with local non-profits, and raising awareness on campus through speaker events, discussions and more.
full_description: United Against Inequities in Disease (UAID) is committed to identifying and addressing health inequalities in Chicago’s South Side, as well as raising awareness on campus about health inequities. UAID strives to make our country’s healthcare system more accessible and comprehensible to those who need it most by forming partnerships with non-profits and faith organizations in neighboring communities, as well as health professionals. The emphasis is always on collaboration, inclusiveness, and empowerment of partner organizations. On campus, UAID seeks to start conversations on different kinds of health inequities through speaker events, discussions, screenings, etc. Our work implies constant critical thinking and discussion on privilege, equity and impact. With each Community Health Project that we take on, our chapter begins with an assessment of our community through data collection, meetings with local organizations, and interviews with individuals. Armed with this information, we then develop a targeted, long-term action plan centered around partnership with and empowerment of local partner organizations. We compile our findings and present the results of our work in a publishable report. On campus, we seek to bridge the gap between the University and Chicago by bringing in speakers that are not only academics but Chicagoland health professionals and representatives from our local partners. We hope to foster open, nuanced conversations on the intersections of health, social class, race, gender, in Chicago and beyond.

additional_info.Parent Organization Name and Website::
United Against Inequities in Disease
http://www.uaid.org

name: University Ballet of Chicago
description_preview: UBallet seeks to promote a love of ballet and provide opportunities for technical training through free weekly classes, open to members of the University and Hyde Park community; as well as putting on two full-length ballet performances a year.
full_description: University Ballet is a Recognized Student Organization at the University of Chicago that offers ballet to undergraduates, graduates, and members of the community. We promote a love of all dance, but specifically focus on enabling everyone to appreciate the art of ballet. We do this by offering 3 free classes every week for all levels. We also present two full-length ballets every year, for which people of all dance backgrounds are encouraged to audition. UBallet typically performs classical ballets, though it also performs at select dance showcases throughout the year. Our main goal is to share our love of ballet which is enforced by our classes and performances.

name: University Community Service Center
description_preview: UCSC's goal is to support students in becoming productive, thoughtful citizens and effective, inspiring leaders in their communities and professions.
full_description: The University Community Service Center (UCSC) is one of 20 departments under theCampus and Student Life(CSL) division that serves the University's 5,000 undergraduates and 10,000 graduate and professional school students. UCSC provides students with service opportunities that complement a rigorous academic experience. UCSC encourages students to explore Chicago, to make meaningful connections with diverse communities throughout the city, to develop friendships with other social-minded students, and to apply classroom learning to understand and address complex societal issues. UCSC offers different community service options that tailor to student interests: volunteer referral, student-run groups, campus-wide days of service, freshmen pre-orientation service week, community-building and social justice programs, tie-ins with course work, and internships at local organizations, including community non-profits, hospitals, businesses, and government agencies. UCSC's goal is to support students in becoming productive, thoughtful citizens and effective, inspiring leaders in their communities and professions.

name: University Ministry of Christ Church Chicago
description_preview: The University Ministry of Christ Church Chicago comes alongside students (grad and undergrad) as they pursue their academic goals. Together, we live out our Christian faith through building community and meeting regularly to study the Bible together.

name: University of Chicago Association of Peruvian Students

full_description: The University of Chicago Association of Peruvian Students (UCAPS)’s mission is to connect the University of Chicago with Peru, and vice versa. We want more Peruvians to study, do research, teach; and, in general, get affiliated with the University of Chicago. Furthermore, we want the University of Chicago and its community to learn more about Peru and become more interested in our country’s issues, doing more research about Peru and promoting alliances with Peruvian institutions, among other initiatives.

name: University of Chicago Ki-Aikido Club
description_preview: The UChicago Ki-Aikido Club trains in the dynamic martial art of Shin Shin Tōitsu Aikidō (Ki-Aikidō). All are welcome; no prior experience is necessary.
full_description: Shin Shin Tōitsu Aikidōis a highly developed form of the Japanese martial art ofAikidōfounded byUeshiba MoriheiSensei, and further developed by his top student,Tōhei KōichiSensei.Shin Shin Tōitsu Aikidōis often calledKi-Aikidōoutside of Japan. Shin Shin Tōitsu Aikidōembodies the essence of Japanesebudō. It is a true martial art with roots in the ancient martial arts and esoteric disciplines of Japan,and it is a way to understand and become one withKi.It is also a very effective method of self-defense, and a way to develop optimal physical and mental health.The principles ofShin Shin To ItsuAikidōare applicable in all circumstances. Training at the University of Chicago Ki-Aikidō Club includes unarmed techniques, weapons arts, and a form of training calledTaigi. Members of our Club train inKi-Aikidōand Ki Development, orShin Shin Tōitsu Dō.We experience this unique training first hand in ourDōjō.

name: University of Chicago Political Union
description_preview: A non-partisan forum for political discourse on salient issues in the world and on campus.

Our team plans 4-5 events per quarter ranging from forums to debates on a myriad of topics. We invite experts from all around the country to participate with a particular emphasis on Chicago politics and issues.
